componenttext: The one we’ve have done, yes, it’s ahead of it, but that’s one of one at this point.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: And then going into Q3 and Q4, I was just looking at the tertiary guidance, and it looks like you guys came in really great in Q2. Is it just being conservative a little bit in Q3-Q4, and just not get too far ahead of yourself, because it looks like the i
componenttext: And then going into Q3 and Q4, I was just looking at the tertiary guidance, and it looks like you guys came in really great in Q2. Is it just being conservative a little bit in Q3-Q4, and just not get too far ahead of yourself, because it looks like the it kind of declines a little bit in Q3 and Q4?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, if you do the math, it basically is kind of assuming that it’s stays kind of flat the last two quarters, but third quarter we kind of did expect a little low, maybe fourth quarter may be a little higher, so hopefully there’s some upside
componenttext: Well, I think, if you do the math, it basically is kind of assuming that it’s stays kind of flat the last two quarters, but third quarter we kind of did expect a little low, maybe fourth quarter may be a little higher, so hopefully there’s some upside there.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: And then definitely on the Bakken, it looks great. I’m curious you threw out the 60 days, 90 days on some of the wells that like the Porcupine wells and a few of those, could you talk about maybe reserves on those wells in particular and sort of how you
componenttext: And then definitely on the Bakken, it looks great. I’m curious you threw out the 60 days, 90 days on some of the wells that like the Porcupine wells and a few of those, could you talk about maybe reserves on those wells in particular and sort of how you look to the actual booking of your proved reserves so far?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: We’re pretty much using a tight decline for the reserves based on the 30-day average. So we use a (inaudible) point of 1.6 and final decline rate of about 8%. If you stick in the 30-day rates and apply that, you’ll get the reserves, but that’s how w
componenttext: We’re pretty much using a tight decline for the reserves based on the 30-day average. So we use a (inaudible) point of 1.6 and final decline rate of about 8%. If you stick in the 30-day rates and apply that, you’ll get the reserves, but that’s how we’re assigning reserves for those wells at this point.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: What are you thinking on, do you carry throughout a year-end exit rate for the Bakken, just kind of looking at where you are and I know you throughout for 2011 on average kind of how it’s looking to double?
componenttext: What are you thinking on, do you carry throughout a year-end exit rate for the Bakken, just kind of looking at where you are and I know you throughout for 2011 on average kind of how it’s looking to double?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010

componenttext: I don’t know that we want to throw out actually fourth quarter rate or December rate at this point, but obviously with the accelerated drilling program, with getting the third rig going and getting this fourth rig going, obviously we expect a pretty big ramp up between now and the end of the year.

componenttext: The proved reserves are relatively small. I don’t have that exactly in front of me, but it’s probably on a proved basis, $15 million, $16 million if you’re looking for proved reserve. componenttext: And then in terms of looking at this thing as far as HBP what do you need to do to hold all your acreage? Is the protected [ph] five rigs what you basically need to run, or is it something less than that?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: To hold all the operated units that we’re forecasting, it’s five. That’s what we’ve scheduled out and that’s through 2011. We haven’t included the Almond and Northeast Foothills in that number. But you know how the industry goes and what we se
componenttext: To hold all the operated units that we’re forecasting, it’s five. That’s what we’ve scheduled out and that’s through 2011. We haven’t included the Almond and Northeast Foothills in that number. But you know how the industry goes and what we see, you probably would have to add something for that area. But it depends on when you start drilling it. If you wait till 2012, you may not have to add a rig at all.

componenttext: Significant part. I think, we have to maintain the five rigs through, if you exclude Almond Northeast Foothills. I think it’s through mid-2012 before it’s all held.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Dave Kistler of Simmons & Company. Please go ahead.
componenttext: The next question is from Dave Kistler of Simmons & Company. Please go ahead.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Following up on a few Bakken questions. Can you talk about the completion techniques you guys are using there? Are you doing plug-and-perf or sliding sleeve?
componenttext: Following up on a few Bakken questions. Can you talk about the completion techniques you guys are using there? Are you doing plug-and-perf or sliding sleeve?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: No. We’re trying to standardize that. We’re going to use ball/sleeve method. The plug-and-perf, we’ve had some complications with the wireline, so we’re finding ball/sleeve is probably the most cost effective and expeditious to your stimulation ti
componenttext: No. We’re trying to standardize that. We’re going to use ball/sleeve method. The plug-and-perf, we’ve had some complications with the wireline, so we’re finding ball/sleeve is probably the most cost effective and expeditious to your stimulation timing and removes need for that wireline. So we’re using that method.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of coming up with your assessment of reserves for the play, you talked about doing three wells per section. Can you talk about how you got the comfort level around those three wells per section?
componenttext: In terms of coming up with your assessment of reserves for the play, you talked about doing three wells per section. Can you talk about how you got the comfort level around those three wells per section?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, it’s down to 3P, number one, so, I mean, generally, the one offset is proved and the third offset is either possible to bring on how it’s spaced. I mean, that’s just based on what you’re recovering today as the individual wells and y
componenttext: Well, I mean, it’s down to 3P, number one, so, I mean, generally, the one offset is proved and the third offset is either possible to bring on how it’s spaced. I mean, that’s just based on what you’re recovering today as the individual wells and you look at the amount of oil in place across a section or a unit. It looks like it’s going to take at least three wells to get a reasonable recovery.

componenttext: Other than we’re negotiating still with lots of people on that, we don’t have any definitive agreements at this point other than the Lost Cabin. We’re working diligently in various stages with several people; we don’t have anything to announce.

componenttext: If I recall correctly, in the past you’d highlighted that potentially by third quarter, fourth quarter, you have a couple different potential contracts that could come through, I think LaBarge facility, the KBRW [ph]. Can you give us any added color on that?

componenttext: Just a few things. Talking about McComb Smithdale earlier, you were saying that you were drilling some more wells with the idea of, I guess, state wise or improving production out there, the wells that you’re drilling out there at this point, were they part of your original Phase 1 recoverability estimates for a well for McComb?

componenttext: You’re talking about big Phase 1 or you’re talking about Phase 1 of McComb?

componenttext: I mean just in general, whatever McComb’s contribution was rolling out into the overall Phase 1, the wells you are drilling, are they now going beyond what that recoverability estimate was?

componenttextpreview: No. This is just an area of the field that’s part of the development plan. I do believe that these wells are being drilled in what’s call the West McComb unit at least at one or two of them were in the West McComb unit, which was a small tack on unit,
componenttext: No. This is just an area of the field that’s part of the development plan. I do believe that these wells are being drilled in what’s call the West McComb unit at least at one or two of them were in the West McComb unit, which was a small tack on unit, but that’s all part of the same reservoir.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Noel, if you go back, we kind of reduced our budget with the Green Pipeline so probably deferred these wells. These wells might have been drilled in the prior year, but with the Green Pipeline we kind of split some of the capital. So now we have the (inau
componenttext: Noel, if you go back, we kind of reduced our budget with the Green Pipeline so probably deferred these wells. These wells might have been drilled in the prior year, but with the Green Pipeline we kind of split some of the capital. So now we have the (inaudible) 2010 to drill these wells. So they are being drilled for McComb Smithdale.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Looking into what you’re looking at for the rest of the year, it seems to me on the tertiary guidance, basically, if you just keep tertiary production flat for the rest of the year, you would essentially make the new guidance the 28,000. Included in tha
componenttext: Looking into what you’re looking at for the rest of the year, it seems to me on the tertiary guidance, basically, if you just keep tertiary production flat for the rest of the year, you would essentially make the new guidance the 28,000. Included in that which fields are you assuming that you’d have further uplift and which fields are you assuming would continue or start to decline?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, we are going to see uplifts in Tinsley, Heidelberg, Delhi, and probably Lockhart Crossing, we just said we have five wells we’re going to put in there and may be some at McComb, Smithdale probably flat to increasing, but I think you have to rem
componenttext: I guess, we are going to see uplifts in Tinsley, Heidelberg, Delhi, and probably Lockhart Crossing, we just said we have five wells we’re going to put in there and may be some at McComb, Smithdale probably flat to increasing, but I think you have to remember that Mallalieu is a mature field, Eucutta is a mature field and Brookhaven are all fairly large mature fields. And so you might see a little bit of run-off. Though it’s not a exaggerated run-off, but some run-off, in 2% to 3% I think is what we saw quart-to-quarter.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: A few things, if you recall, Noel, kind of like stair step or wherever you tend to get a bump and then you get flat a little bit and then you get bump, and so we just expect third quarter to be relatively flat to second. Now fourth, we hope that we get a
componenttext: A few things, if you recall, Noel, kind of like stair step or wherever you tend to get a bump and then you get flat a little bit and then you get bump, and so we just expect third quarter to be relatively flat to second. Now fourth, we hope that we get a little bump again, but yes, you’re right mathematically, it’s basically assuming flat for rest of the year for that forecast.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Just one Bakken question, you were talking about or actually in the press release, it says that you’re assuming 34,000 of Almond and the Northeast Foothills are being excluded from your estimates, but by my count that would still leave another 40,000 so
componenttext: Just one Bakken question, you were talking about or actually in the press release, it says that you’re assuming 34,000 of Almond and the Northeast Foothills are being excluded from your estimates, but by my count that would still leave another 40,000 some net acres in those two areas. So are you saying that you’re including those, assuming that they are prospective in your count?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it’s about 10% of the total.
componenttext: Yes, it’s about 10% of the total.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: 10% of your overall Bakken total, right?
componenttext: 10% of your overall Bakken total, right?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: The reservoir other than being higher permeability, it’s really not much different than most of the other reservoirs we have, everything we have in the Gulf Coast is a sandstone. But as far as faster response, I mean, the real issue there, Eric, is the
componenttext:
The reservoir other than being higher permeability, it’s really not much different than most of the other reservoirs we have, everything we have in the Gulf Coast is a sandstone. But as far as faster response, I mean, the real issue there, Eric, is the fact that the reservoir is very depleted. We’re looking at a minimum of a year to pressurize the reservoir up in order for it to respond. So our historical has been six months to nine months from first injection. So that’s on the long side of that.
I think, once we get it to pressure, I think with the permeability we can see some pretty good rates, but as far as being early I don’t think you’ll see that. And then the reserves in Oyster Bayou are, the majority of that 25 million barrels to 30 million barrels that we’re having to see reach complex. I think, it’s two to three (inaudible) or something like that.

componenttextpreview: Well, we have given bits and pieces, it’s hard because we don’t have our 2011 capital budget then, precisely, but preliminarily, I think you can take our slide show and that pie chart that we have for 2010, I don’t think it’s going to change too m
componenttext:
Well, we have given bits and pieces, it’s hard because we don’t have our 2011 capital budget then, precisely, but preliminarily, I think you can take our slide show and that pie chart that we have for 2010, I don’t think it’s going to change too much in 2011. Pipelines are still going to be somewhere in that 200 range; instead of the Green Pipeline it’s going to be the Greencore.
What you’ll probably see depending on what happens with the sale of Haynesville, the Haynesville number could go away completely or at least go down and maybe a little bit, but you’re going to spend a little bit more in the Bakken because we’re going to add rigs.
So, I mean that’s kind of the high level, but the conceptual deal is just we haven’t given precise numbers. That depending on prices may still be a little bit above our cash flow, but it’s obviously, much less, and we expect it to be less than this year just because we expect some production increases. 2012 that’s a little further out, but I don’t think conceptually that will be too much different either. So I think you’ll see a budget over $1 billion plus or minus, maybe 10% or something near 15% and the allocation somewhat similar.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Denbury Resources and Encore Energy Partners Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. Later, we will conduct a question-and-answer
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Denbury Resources and Encore Energy Partners Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. Later, we will conduct a question-and-answer session and instructions will be given at that time. (Operator instructions) Also, as a reminder, today’s teleconference is being recorded.
At this time, I will turn the conference call over to your host, CEO, Phil Rykhoek. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tony. Welcome to Denbury and ENP’s third quarter 2010 conference call. Similar to our normal style, we will cover Denbury first, and then follow with an update on ENP, and then open it up for questions. With me today I have Tracy Evans, our P
componenttext:
Thank you, Tony. Welcome to Denbury and ENP’s third quarter 2010 conference call. Similar to our normal style, we will cover Denbury first, and then follow with an update on ENP, and then open it up for questions. With me today I have Tracy Evans, our President and COO; Mark Allen, our Senior Vice President and CFO; and Bob Cornelius, our Senior Vice President of Operations.
Operations and performance at Denbury continue to go well and 2010 is shaping up to be a great year for us. I won’t spend a lot of time reviewing 2010 today, but as I did last time, I want to commend our employees for their hard work in handling and absorbing all of the extra work generated by this constant stream of transactions and activity this year, primarily related to the Encore acquisition in March.
It’s a tribute to our employees that we have been able to outperform and exceed our 2010 projections in almost every way, while still handling all of the transition and other extra work generated by our acquisitions and divestitures.
Our asset sales have exceeded their projected upper limit of $1 billion by $150 million or so, and we still have one potential sale transaction in the works, and that’s the sale of ENP.
We’ve not only cleaned up our balance sheet and reduced the debt incurred for the Encore acquisition, but we’ve provided sufficient capital to fund almost all of our 2010 spending. If ENP closes, we’ll have also raised enough funds to more than cover 2011 as well.
Further, while our asset sales have achieved the desired results, or if you want to put it in another way, we’ve basically sold these assets to more than we paid for them, I think it’s important to note that after raising more than $1 billion from asset sales, we still have more proved reserves today than we did in March when we closed Encore. We plan to provide more details on this at our forthcoming Analyst Meeting, but I thought it might be good just to remind you of these highlights.
Looking more specifically at this quarter, our tertiary production is doing very well, ahead of forecast again. Expenses are on track. So, those always make a nice combination. Our Green Pipeline is almost finished.
We’ve added 1 Tcf of proved reserve this year at Jackson Dome, we just closed on Riley Ridge, which gives us a lot of optionality for CO2 in the Rockies and we expect to close on the Haynesville in early December.
As I mentioned we would last quarter, we remarketed these assets, and as part of that effort, received what we perceive to be a good price for these properties, at least, in today’s natural gas market. Of course, our primary reason to sell these assets is to focus our capital expenditures and attention on our core EOR assets and the Bakken where we believe we have better returns in today’s commodity price environment.
Conceptually, the funds that were invested in Haynesville in 2010 will be reallocated to the Bakken in 2011. This sale will slightly lower our overall 2011 production growth as the Haynesville wells are high rate wells on a Boe basis that we believe that the quality and economics of our investments will be better without these gassy assets. We are still hopeful that we can sell ENP by year-end, although, admittedly, we are getting late in the year, but our goal is still to do that.
So, with that introduction, I’ll let the other guys walk you through the quarter in more details, starting with Mark.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phil. As reported in our press release, Denbury had net income for the third quarter of $29.1 million or $0.07 per basic common share. However, our net income adjusted to exclude fair value hedging changes, Encore merger-related costs and the i
componenttext:
Thank you, Phil. As reported in our press release, Denbury had net income for the third quarter of $29.1 million or $0.07 per basic common share. However, our net income adjusted to exclude fair value hedging changes, Encore merger-related costs and the impact from a revision to our accounting for CO2 discovery cost was $52.7 million or $0.13 per share.
As I’ve typically done, I will primarily focus on the sequential results of the second and third quarters of 2010. During the third quarter of 2010, our tertiary production averaged 29,531 barrels per day, 4% higher than our Q2 tertiary production.
As you recall, last quarter we increased our annual 2010 tertiary production guidance to 28,000 barrels per day, and we are now increasing it again to 28,750 barrels per day due to the continued production increases during the third quarter. Bob will discuss more about that momentarily.
As updated at the end of Q2, our forecasted production for 2010, excluding the divested southern assets for the entire year, was estimated at 77,000 Boe per day, which includes 8,600 Boe per day associated with Encore Energy Partners or ENP.
With the announced sale of our Haynesville and East Texas assets and the sale of our Cleveland Sand assets, we have revised our annual 2010 estimated production excluding all asset sales to approximately 70,000 BOE per day, including approximately 8,600 BOE per day associated with ENPs production.
Our production for Q3, adjusted to exclude production associated with all asset divestitures, was approximately 71,824 BOE per day, including 8,630 BOE per day related to ENP.
We anticipate that our fourth quarter production excluding production associated with Haynesville and East Texas asset sale, which will not be included in our results until closing, will be about the same or slightly higher than our adjusted third quarter average. We plan to provide more information regarding our production guidance for the rest of 2010 and 2011 at our upcoming Analyst Meeting.
Our average oil price received for the quarter including derivative settlements was $71.63 per barrel in Q3 as compared to $71.68 per barrel in Q2. Our NYMEX oil price differential was $3.85 per barrel below NYMEX in the third quarter as compared to $4.13 per barrel below NYMEX in Q2.
Differentials in our northern properties were negatively impacted during a portion of both the second and third quarters as a result of a temporary refinery shutdown in pipeline shutdown, although much of the differential was offset by higher net prices for a Gulf Coast production.
Although our lease operating expenses were approximately 3% from Q2 and Q3, our lease operating expenses on a per BOE basis increased more significantly from $16.69 per BOE in Q2 to $18.43 per BOE in Q3. The increase on a per BOE basis was due primarily to higher workover cost in Q3 and the impact of the asset of the sales which had a lower cost per BOE.
Excluding the LOE in production associated with the Haynesville sale from our results, our Q3 LOE per BOE would have been approximately $19.62 per BEO. I would expect our LOE per BOE to be in the low to mid $19 million going forward.
G&A expenses increased by $5.9 million from $4.07 per barrel in Q2 to $5.19 per BEO in Q3, due primarily to higher personnel related costs and/or production as a result of the asset sales. Going forward, I’d expect our G&A to increase slightly as we continue to add new employees.
We’ll continue to have ongoing merger-related cost associated with integration and severance, but we anticipate this month to be lower going forward depending on severance cost which accounted for the best majority of our cost of Q3. Approximately $1.8 million of the Q3 Encore merger-related costs were still associated with non-cash equity compensation expense for severed employees.
Interest expense, net of capitalized interest, increased sequentially from $43.5 million to $53.3 million, primarily related to lower capitalized interest in Q3 due to a portion of the Green Pipeline being placed into service at the end of the second quarter.
Capitalized interest was $10.9 million this quarter as compared to $23.9 million last quarter. Average debt outstanding was $2.8 billion in Q3 as compared to $3.2 billion in Q2, as our proceeds from the southern asset sale in mid Q2 went to pay down our bank debt.
Going forward, we expect that our capitalized interest will be around $10 million in the fourth quarter depending on when the rest of the Green Pipeline is placed into service.
We currently anticipate that the remaining portion of the Green Pipeline to be placed into service around the end of 2010. For 2011, we expect capitalized interest per quarter to be slightly lower once the Green Pipeline goes into service.
Our bank debt at September 30 was $120 million on a $1.6 billion bank credit line and we had $240 million outstanding on ENP’s bank line. Our bank debt is currently $225 million after closing the Riley Ridge acquisition, but we expect to repay a significant portion of this with the proceeds from the Haynesville sale, which should close by the first part of December.
Our anticipated capital spending for 2010, excluding acquisitions and capitalized interest remains at $1.06 billion, and we currently anticipate that our bank debt would be around $100 million at year end depending of timing of capital expenditures.
For 2011, we preliminary see our capital expenditures around $1 billion, potentially $100 million to $200 million above anticipated cash flows. However, as Phil mentioned, if we are successful in selling our ENP ownership, the proceeds from that would most likely cover all and most of this shortfall.
Our DD&A per BOE was $15.61 per BOE in Q3 as compared to $16.88 per BOE in Q2. As mentioned in our press release, we revised our accounting for CO2 properties in Q3 which resulted in a pre-tax credit of $9.6 million due to the cumulative effect on DD&A related to prior periods. Without this adjustment, our DD&A per BOE would have been $16.95 per BOE slightly higher than our Q2 average.
As a result of our accounting change, we may incur expense in future periods that funds our spent in search of CO2 reserves on properties with no existing proved or probable reserves. We expensed $1.2 million associated with these costs in Q3.
With regard to income taxes, we currently anticipate that during 2010, we will be able to deduct the cost of our Green Pipeline that we put into service mid-year and to deduct the cost of the remaining portion of the Green Pipeline if we put into service before year end. This should help to limit our current tax expense and help to show additional tax on asset dispositions.
We continue to see our current tax increase slightly due primarily to state taxes, but state taxes on asset sales may not be completely offset and our taxable income continues to increase with higher oil prices.
With that, I’ll pass it to Tracy.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark. As we released several weeks ago, we have added an additional Tcf of CO2 reserves in the Jackson Dome area during 2010, approximately 400 Bcf in our DRI Dock prospect and approximately 600 Bcf as a result of our Anderson well at Gluckstad
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark. As we released several weeks ago, we have added an additional Tcf of CO2 reserves in the Jackson Dome area during 2010, approximately 400 Bcf in our DRI Dock prospect and approximately 600 Bcf as a result of our Anderson well at Gluckstadt field, which encountered original reservoir pressure, confirming our geological interpretation that faults within the Gluckstadt field are sealing, and therefore, the field may contain even greater volumes of CO2.
3D seismic interpretation of the Gluckstadt field indicates that our additional fault block is similar to the fault block the Anderson well was drilled, but additional drilling will be required to test and prove up the additional CO2 reserves in these unreal fault blocks.
In our DRI Dock prospect, production testing and 3D seismic interpretation resulted in reducing the original reserve potential of the prospect, but the prospect will add additional CO2 deliverability as well as the 400 Bcf of additional proved CO2 reserves.
There continues to be a considerable amount of technical work ongoing in the Jackson Dome area, and while DRI Dock’s potential reserves is reduced based on our additional testing and the three seismic interpretations, the potential reserves at Gluckstadt has increased based on the results of the Anderson well coupled with the 3D seismic over Gluckstadt.
As a result of all these efforts in the Jackson Dome area, we have added an additional Tcf of proved CO2 reserves, while maintaining our probable reserve potential between 2 and 3 Tcf of CO2 reserves in the Jackson Dome area.
We have completed our drilling program for 2010 in Jackson Dome area and we’ll begin additional drilling during the first quarter of 2011. We have delivered an excess of 1 Bcf of CO2 per day from Jackson Dome on several occasions to-date, and thus, we are very confident of delivering the CO2 volumes required for our CO2 EOR operations going forward.
As well with our Jackson Dome work, we continue to work with potential sources of anthropogenic CO2 in the Gulf Coast and the Rocky Mountains. Activity in many of our contract at anthropogenic sources appears to be moving forward again, with hope that several of these projects will reach the financing stage by year-end or early first quarter with construction phase starting shortly thereafter.
As we have previously announced, we have closed our acquisition of a 42.5% non-operated working interest in the Riley Ridge project in Southwest Wyoming. This project is located in the prolific LaBarge field and will produce methane, helium and CO2.
First production is expected in late 2011, but that time all CO2 volumes will be re-injected back into the reservoir. The timing of capture and transportation of the CO2 from the project to the EOR fields remains uncertain at this time as we continue to negotiate for additional CO2 volumes.
At the present time, we have not signed any additional contracts for CO2 volumes, but are working to finalize several contracts and we continue to work with existing and new projects to acquire additional CO2 volumes in the Gulf Coast and in the Rocky Mountains.
Switching to the Bakken, we operated three rigs during the entire third quarter. Initially we expected to complete and bring on five additional wells during the quarter, but due to casing issues we were only able to bring two of the five wells on production. One additional well was completed, but due to a well control incident on another well on the same pad, the completed well remain shut-in at this time.
The fifth well expected to be completed in the quarter developed the casing issue within a liner during stimulation and that stimulation work had to be suspended. The liner has been repaired and we are preparing to finish the stimulation and completion on the well within the next couple of weeks. Although the two completion issues are extremely disappointing, we are certain that we will get both wells completed and put online in the near future.
Obviously, our expected third quarter production was effective substantially, and while we will bring on the three wells planned in the third quarter during the fourth quarter as well as our recently planned fourth quarter wells, it will be difficult to achieve our expected annual average production in the block in the 4,600 BOEs per day.
While we will most likely be short on the industry average, we expect to meet our originally expected exit rate and may actually exceed it, with up to eight wells being completed and brought online during the quarter, barring any other unforeseen delays.
To-date, in the fourth quarter the Jorgenson 34-9 and the Joseph 11-1H were initially tested at 1,472 and 1,329 BOEs per day, respectively, and we expect to have an additional four wells brought on production, hopefully, by the end of the month based on our current completion schedule.
Looking toward 2011, our fourth rig is currently being mobilized to its location in the Cherry area and the fifth rig is expected to arrive during the last week of November and it will be located in the Cherry area as well. While neither of these rigs will contribute to the production in the fourth quarter, our 2011 drilling program appears to be slightly ahead of schedule.
We have secured three fracs per month and are still working to secure the fourth, which is expected to be sufficient to manage our five rig drilling program for 2011.
While the availability of frac crews is still very tight, we have been able to obtain the necessary frac dates for wells that were delayed due to the completion issues we experienced without compromising our completion schedule on future wells.
On the completion side, we are continuing to evaluate our results as well as our results of completions performed and wells where we have a non-operated position. We expect to provide additional information on our expected completions at our upcoming Analyst Meeting as well as in our 2011 expected annual production from the Bakken.
With that, I’ll turn it over to Bob to discuss CO2 EOR operations and operations in general.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tracy. I’ll give you guys a quick update on the major CO2 EOR fields, their production rates and pipeline construction progress during the third quarter.As reported tertiary production averaged 29,531 net BOEs for the quarter, that’s an i
componenttext:
Thank you, Tracy. I’ll give you guys a quick update on the major CO2 EOR fields, their production rates and pipeline construction progress during the third quarter.
As reported tertiary production averaged 29,531 net BOEs for the quarter, that’s an increase of 1,024 net BOEs a 3%, 4% and 5% compared to the second quarter 2010. Based on this increase in tertiary production, we are raising average daily tertiary production guidance to 28,750 net BOEs for the year, that’s an 18% increase year-over-year in average EOR production rates.
With the addition of the Oyster Bayou field earlier this year, we now have 14 different field areas under CO2 injection in six of our nine CO2 expansion areas. Overall, we continue to have great success in EOR operations with five of our fields exhibiting double digit production growth during the third quarter. I’ll break these down by phases.
Phase 1, which is of course our most mature area consisted of six field in Southwest Mississippi, one in Louisiana. That increased 32 barrels per day over the second quarter with an average daily rate of 12,281 net BOEs per day.
McComb, Smithdale area increased in average of 325 net BOEs per day or 15% quarter-to-quarter. The increase is due to four well drilling program or pattern expansion at West McComb area that was completed during the period.
Brookhaven quarterly production averaged 3,323 net BOEs, a slight increase over the second quarter due to a single well completion during September. That well responded within an initial production rate in excess of 800 BOEs per day on a gross basis and of course, this well is expected to decline from these production rates during the next quarter, but the production rate from this well illustrates a potential of a mature CO2 tertiary program.
Also, in Brookhaven, a four-well WAG pattern, that’s Water Alternating Gas program was initiated during September in an area of the reservoir that required injection profile improvements. Several wells with high GORs, that’s CO2 to oil production rates, were tested to establish a base line production.
In water, CO2 injection cycles began in late June. Now we anticipate additional oil production to be established from this WAG tests started by year end.
Lockhart Crossing, which is a location of our analyst tour, is going to be later this month. That continues to perform better than expected with third quarter production exceeding the second quarter performance by 197 barrels with a growth of 15% quarter-to-quarter.
At Lockhart Crossing, the team continues to closely monitor the reservoir pressure, they have added producing wells, they have also added a booster pump to improve CO2 injection rates. This is seven consecutive quarters that Lockhart Crossing has increased production rates.
The Mallalieu field actually decreased about 349 net BOEs per day or 10% quarter-to-quarter because Mallalieu is a mature CO2 field and most likely continued this decline over time.
Jumping to Page 2, we experienced 261 net BOE or 3% increase in production rate as compared to the second quarter. Heidelberg had a 950 net BOE per day increase or 51% quarter-to-quarter. The team continues to aggressively expand the Heidelberg CO2 field and added approximately 20 wells, they were placed online during the quarter.
On a quarter-to-quarter basis Soso field was 191 net BOEs or 6% less than the second quarter. Soso filed is nearing its peak production with probably only one near-term injection pattern to be developed in the Bailey zone.
Eucutta field produces an average of 341 net BOEs less than the second quarter. That decline was due to a facility downtime associated with maintenance of heat exchangers at that main facility.
In Phase 3, Tinsley increased 776 net BOEs per day or almost 15% quarter-to-quarter. The reservoir continues to perform better than predicted and is now our highest volume EOR field with an average third quarter production rate of 6,024 BOE net barrels.
Tinsley aggressively developed during 2010 with an investment in excess to $50 million. They added well count and expanded separation and recycled facilities during the year. Well work and infrastructure continues in the east fault block, that is the largest fault block during the fourth quarter, and we’ll continue to boost and improve production through the end of the year.
Cranfield is a Phase 4 field. It increased 5%, or 43 net BOEs quarter-to-quarter. As previously reported, the 2010 drilling program was delayed slightly. The drilling rig did return in August to complete the program.
Jet pumps were also installed or will be installed upon initial completion of the producing wells. These jet pumps will allow new wells to be placed on line and on production quicker than waiting for the reservoir itself to respond. We have used jet pumps in other fields to improve response time in oil production so we should see continued improvement in the rates at Cranfield.
Delhi is our Phase 5. We had a 20 well drilling program and that work is being completed. Production flow lines and injection lines will be completed in connected to test sites one, two during the fourth quarter. CO2 injection rates will increase once these injection lines are tied in. So we are expecting improvement in production at Delhi.
Third quarter production averaged 511 net BOEs per day, which was a slight decline over the prior quarter. This decline rate was due to production been shut into a flow line that had to be repaired.
Phase 7 and 8 development is moving forward and on schedule. As stated before, Oyster Bayou began injection in June. Currently CO2 injection in Aneth field averages 77 million cubic feet a day in the five wells. We have two rigs completing wells for both production and injection.
We are waiting for our Corp of Engineers permit to start our CO2 injection facility in the field. That permit has taken slightly longer than anticipated. It’s probably something that’s probably a bit more common these days. We are hoping that that permit will be granted in the next 30 days, and if so, we would expect initial production from Oyster Bayou to be about a year from now, November, December 2011. At our Hastings field we are running six capital rigs, preparing the CO2 injection for December 2010 as the Green Pipeline nears its completion phase.
Shifting to the Green Pipeline, construction is almost finished to Hastings in the Galveston Bay. The pipeline has been completely welded out. It is being filled for hydro testing. The pipeline on the west side of the Bay is also completely welded out.
We are doing a final tie-in and that work should be completed in the next week. The line is scheduled for hydro testing in approximately two weeks. Testing and commissioning the pipeline should be completed and the line completely in service and delivering CO2 to the Hastings field by year-end.
Once the Green line is completed, we’ll move to the Conroe line. We are working right now on the engineering design of that Conroe line. We are looking to pose right away environmental permit for the Conroe line. That Conroe line would be 80 to 85 mile 20-inch line that will go from southwest to Beaumont into the Conroe field. We are currently estimating the pipeline will be completed around 2014, another four-year project.
The 20-inch Greencore Pipeline is the 232 mile pipeline running from Lost Cabin, Wyoming up to Bell Creek field in Montana. The right-of-way survey is ongoing with 97% of the survey completed and offers made to 100% right-of-way owners and about 55% of those owners have been signed up.
Preliminary engineering is completed on that line. We are looking at pipe specifications. We’ve placed an order for about 50% of the 20-inch pipe. We worked on the environmental assessment, which is moving along as scheduled.
The first 115 miles of that pipeline are targeted for construction during August through December of next year, and then the remaining 117 miles will be completed in August through December of 2012. So we should have injection in the Bell Creek sometime late 2012.
We are working with Bell Creek field in Southern Montana. That will be our first Rocky EOR project. We are preparing the idle wells for CO2 injection in service. So far we have 31 injection wells, which have been prepared for injection and we are expecting to complete the additional 10 injection wells to be reworked by year-end.
I want to also point out, Tracy mentioned Jackson Dome, we have produced an average of 866 million cubic feet a day during the third quarter, slightly higher than forecasted, and also as he pointed out, we did have a BCF production out of those wells. So we do have the rate at Jackson Dome to sustain our operations.
Lease operating expense, third quarter consolidated operating expenses were $131 million, which Mark reported, approximately 3% greater than the second quarter of 2010. Our lease operating costs increased $1.74. If you break that in, the reasons for those increases, first one was increased workover expenses at the CO2 fields.
We are trying to accelerate some of that work before cold weather slips in. We also had to re-class of certain salary expenses from G&A to LOE on the Encore legacy properties. And then, finally, the divestiture of the southern assets, which had a lower operating cost per BOE that caused our cost in the third quarter to increase.
With that, I’ll turn it back over to Phil.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: As announced last week, the distribution for the third quarter of 2010 was approved at $0.50 per unit, the same distribution rate as Q2. Our cash available for distribution in Q3 was $24.7 million as compared to $25 million in Q2, lower due primarily to l
componenttext:
As announced last week, the distribution for the third quarter of 2010 was approved at $0.50 per unit, the same distribution rate as Q2. Our cash available for distribution in Q3 was $24.7 million as compared to $25 million in Q2, lower due primarily to lower production and price realization.
Our coverage ratio for the third quarter was just under 1.1 times. However, on a year-to-date basis, it was at 1.13 times. Production for the third quarter totaled 8,630 BOE per day as compared to 8,841 BOE per day in the second quarter of 2010. Going forward, we expect production to continue to be on a gradual decline for the remainder of 2010. We repaid $5 million in bank debt during the quarter, bringing our bank debt to $240 million at September 30.
With that, I’ll turn it back to Phil.

componenttextpreview: Hey, just some quick, can you kind of walk me through sort to the Green line in the field. Does the Green line is connected to Oyster Bayou right now, but you are or are not injecting to it because you are waiting on permit there.
componenttext: Hey, just some quick, can you kind of walk me through sort to the Green line in the field. Does the Green line is connected to Oyster Bayou right now, but you are or are not injecting to it because you are waiting on permit there.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, if you see the Green line, the Green line is 320 mile pipeline that connects to the south end of NEJD line. Now, it’s complete across Louisiana and the Oyster Bayou. We started injection in Oyster Bayou at June 29 this summer, and right now we hav
componenttext:
Well, if you see the Green line, the Green line is 320 mile pipeline that connects to the south end of NEJD line. Now, it’s complete across Louisiana and the Oyster Bayou. We started injection in Oyster Bayou at June 29 this summer, and right now we have 77 million cubic feet a day going into Oyster Bayou. So that’s been completed for some time, six month through. And then what we are doing right now is, we are completing or had nearly completed the line into Hastings, and that line will be connected into Hastings by December of this year, if all goes well.
What we’re looking at as a permit, at Oyster Bayou, we have to get a wetlands permit, and so that permitting process is ongoing, but I do think that we are very close. We’ve had the permit into the core engineers for approximately 10 months. There is nothing that should be holding it up, so we hope to get that final permit hopefully in next 30 days and it will start construction. The construction of that takes probably nine to 12 month depending on weather conditions to get that recycle facility. If the recycle facility gets done, once that facility is done, they will be able to get things moving in Oyster Bayou.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: So how soon after like, let’s say, it takes 12 months and you get your permits, I mean are you expecting it delayed by the end of the year? Once the facility gets constructed, is there a time lag between getting it online and actually getting old volume
componenttext: So how soon after like, let’s say, it takes 12 months and you get your permits, I mean are you expecting it delayed by the end of the year? Once the facility gets constructed, is there a time lag between getting it online and actually getting old volumes coming through?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, the Oyster value is it was lower pressured than a lot of other fields we’ve started. So it’s going to have a longer fill up pressurization phase. We always knew it was going to take a minimum of 12 months to fill it up. So, it may take a little
componenttext: Scott, the Oyster value is it was lower pressured than a lot of other fields we’ve started. So it’s going to have a longer fill up pressurization phase. We always knew it was going to take a minimum of 12 months to fill it up. So, it may take a little longer than that. Right now, you’re looking at a constructing a facility, getting it online, and first production, honestly, ought to be about simultaneous at this point. We’re hoping to have the facility done a little bit earlier.

componenttext: It has dragged on longer than expected. That’s probably why we mention it. I think it’s probably a sign of the times, I think you’ve seen that in all throughout the industry. But we think we’re pretty close. However, if it does drag on then potentially, we’ve used up a lot of our cushion, potentially production was slipped just a little bit.

componenttext: If you’ve looked at our tight curve, Oyster Bayou is going to reach peak in probably couple of years, maybe at most three. That’s quite different from the type curve that we presented to you, whereas Hastings will probably be actually a little bit longer than average because it is such a large field. So they will respond quite differently.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Moving to the Bakken, can you talk a little bit about the wells that you had sort of the casing issues. What specially went wrong there and how are you, I guess, looking to avoid that going forward?
componenttext: Moving to the Bakken, can you talk a little bit about the wells that you had sort of the casing issues. What specially went wrong there and how are you, I guess, looking to avoid that going forward?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: The primary one was the Franchuk well that the actual well production casing developed a leak during the fifth stage of the frac job. We have not gotten to the bottom of this. 100% sure what the reason was, but it appears that a wrong grade of a joint or
componenttext: The primary one was the Franchuk well that the actual well production casing developed a leak during the fifth stage of the frac job. We have not gotten to the bottom of this. 100% sure what the reason was, but it appears that a wrong grade of a joint or two of casing got put in the well, which was inadvertent, but we’re still researching that. So, at that point in time, you actually have to take some of that pipe out, you got to prepare the service casing. So we’re in a process of doing all that. The second well, we had an issue with the liner. The actual liner parted and we had to fish it out and replace it. So really two different issues.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you think this is a sign of the times with so many rigs running in all these basins, doing lot of these high intensity frac jobs that quality of services is somewhat of a concern or is this just a specific unique situation?
componenttext: Do you think this is a sign of the times with so many rigs running in all these basins, doing lot of these high intensity frac jobs that quality of services is somewhat of a concern or is this just a specific unique situation?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We can put in systems and policies to prevent that. One thing we’re doing is we’re evaluating each piece of all of the casing. We’re doing inspections of the casing before it hits our location. And then we follow that casing from the yard into our f
componenttext: We can put in systems and policies to prevent that. One thing we’re doing is we’re evaluating each piece of all of the casing. We’re doing inspections of the casing before it hits our location. And then we follow that casing from the yard into our field after it’s been inspected. So that part of it that we can prevent and that’s what we’re going to do.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: The Bakken, the fracturing in the Bakken is no different than the fracturing in the Haynesville, the fracturing in the Barnett. Designs are similar in terms of safety factors and things like that. So, as Bob mentioned, managing the casing going forward is
componenttext: The Bakken, the fracturing in the Bakken is no different than the fracturing in the Haynesville, the fracturing in the Barnett. Designs are similar in terms of safety factors and things like that. So, as Bob mentioned, managing the casing going forward is going to be a big issue for us. There’s waste avoided, obviously, and then if you do find it happen again, you can actually run fracturing, which we have done on a couple of wells as well. I’ve never seen this in 27 years where the wrong casing got run. So I hope it’s an anomaly.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then you also had three frac dates and looking to get a fourth and that should take care of five rig program, is that what I’m hearing, right?
componenttext: And then you also had three frac dates and looking to get a fourth and that should take care of five rig program, is that what I’m hearing, right?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: That’s correct.
componenttext: That’s correct.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. Thanks, guys.
componenttext: Okay. All right. Thanks, guys.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott.
componenttext: Thanks, Scott.

componenttextpreview: Thank you. (Operator instructions) Your next question in queue will come from the line of Dan Guffey with Stifel Nicolaus. And your line is open.
componenttext: Thank you. (Operator instructions) Your next question in queue will come from the line of Dan Guffey with Stifel Nicolaus. And your line is open.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, guys. Wondering in Jackson Dome, I know you mentioned looking at 3D at Gluckstadt, it shows additional fault blocks, just wondering timing on drilling additional wells in Jackson Dome?
componenttext: Hi, guys. Wondering in Jackson Dome, I know you mentioned looking at 3D at Gluckstadt, it shows additional fault blocks, just wondering timing on drilling additional wells in Jackson Dome?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We plan three to four wells next year as well. Definitely one of those will be in testing, one of these other fault blocks at Gluckstadt. We’ve had the 3D over Gluckstadt for some time. We had not drilled a well across one of the faults to determine tha
componenttext: We plan three to four wells next year as well. Definitely one of those will be in testing, one of these other fault blocks at Gluckstadt. We’ve had the 3D over Gluckstadt for some time. We had not drilled a well across one of the faults to determine that they truly were separated. We will continue to drill three or four wells here for the next several years.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Moving over to the Bakken, I guess your fourth and fifth rig you guys are going to be bringing on is going to the Cherry area. I was wondering where your three other rigs were and the location of those rigs, and I guess if that’s a function of holding a
componenttext: Moving over to the Bakken, I guess your fourth and fifth rig you guys are going to be bringing on is going to the Cherry area. I was wondering where your three other rigs were and the location of those rigs, and I guess if that’s a function of holding acreage or if you are putting those in the most what you think are the most prospective area?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010

componenttext: Most of the rigs are in the process of holding acreage, but the other three rigs right now, two are in Charlson and one is in Cherry.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010

componenttext: The five rigs program, of course, we developed was to hold acreage and to be able to hold everything other than maybe what’s up there in the Almond and the Foothills area with this program. So that’s how we backed into the rig schedule. So that’s how we’re going to go over the next couple years.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: You should have significant, most of your acreage held by the end of 2011 with that five rig program, is that right?
componenttext: You should have significant, most of your acreage held by the end of 2011 with that five rig program, is that right?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010

componenttext: Most, yes, but not all. It will take probably through ‘12. It might not take five rigs through ‘12, but our current drilling programs will take at least two years to get it fully held. That excludes the Almond, like Phil mentioned. We may or may not get that held.

componenttext: I mean, we’re still forecasting $8 to $10 range. componenttext: Most those employees that didn’t stay because they live in a wrong part of town we’re still having to replace. So most of those are working for us on transition. componenttext: And then with Lockhart Crossing, any impressive growth you guys have seen there. You referenced that’s part of that the installation of booster pump or I guess jet pumps. As this field that has continued to grow a little more than some of the other, are there things you’re learning there that you can apply elsewhere to some legacy field or to some maybe pending fields?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have a whole bunch of things that we’re learning. As you talk about, booster pumps, we’re actually starting several years ago in some of the other legacy field. The booster pump is to help improve CO2 injection, CO2 underground, or CO2 we get into
componenttext:
We have a whole bunch of things that we’re learning. As you talk about, booster pumps, we’re actually starting several years ago in some of the other legacy field. The booster pump is to help improve CO2 injection, CO2 underground, or CO2 we get into reservoir. The more contact we have, the more oil we produce. So, booster pumps have been something that the team has just employed, and then jet pumps are same thing.
At Cranfield we use jet pumps, we started jet pumps. Actually, Soso field was where we stared up, but now we are moving those across the field too. Same thing with WAG. If WAG works at Brookhaven, we’re going to able to employ that across several fields. There are just tools in the tool box that are going to help us to become better. I think Tracy has answered it on the very first question. What are you doing differently now with EOR production? I think it’s a lot of things we’re doing. We’ve learned a lot. We employed all those tools to make this a better production.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is there a point where as you kind of work thought this learning curve, there is a possibility we can see some upward revisions to the reserve estimate or kind of for production outlook for some of these fields?
componenttext: Is there a point where as you kind of work thought this learning curve, there is a possibility we can see some upward revisions to the reserve estimate or kind of for production outlook for some of these fields?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that’s definitely possible. Lot of the fields still are booked in the 13%. So, obviously, we’re not even booked in the 17% in some of these fields yet. So that will be first phase. I think over time as we continue to learn and employ some of t
componenttext: I think that’s definitely possible. Lot of the fields still are booked in the 13%. So, obviously, we’re not even booked in the 17% in some of these fields yet. So that will be first phase. I think over time as we continue to learn and employ some of the new techniques, we’ve talked about some lags, we’ve talked about some other stuffs we’re doing, you’ll see some incremental reserve adds. It’s not we’re going to double it or add 25% or anything, but you’ll start seeing some incremental adds here or there in these fields. When you’ve seen it in Little Creek already, you’ve seen a little bit in Mallalieu per se. It just occurs over time. They are kind of hard to predict when they are going to happen.
