headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning and welcome to the Denbury Resources second quarter 2010 earnings release. All participants will be in a listen-only mode. After today’s presentation, there will be an opportunity to ask questions. Please note this event is being recorded.
componenttext:
Good morning and welcome to the Denbury Resources second quarter 2010 earnings release. All participants will be in a listen-only mode. After today’s presentation, there will be an opportunity to ask questions. Please note this event is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Phil Rykhoek. Please go ahead.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome everybody to Denbury and ENP second quarter conference call. Similar to last time, we plan to talk about Denbury first, then we’ll follow with an update on ENP and then open it up for questions.With me today, I have Tracy Evans, our
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome everybody to Denbury and ENP second quarter conference call. Similar to last time, we plan to talk about Denbury first, then we’ll follow with an update on ENP and then open it up for questions.
With me today, I have Tracy Evans, our President and COO; Mark Allen, our Senior VP and CFO; and Bob Cornelius, our Senior VP of Operations.
As you can see, things at Denbury are continuing to go well. As we highlighted in the press release, our production is ahead of forecast, expenses are on track or below and that’s always a nice combination which allowed us to beat the First Call earnings expectations by a few pennies.
Further, as you may notice, a significant portion of the green pipeline is now in service. We are also quite proud that we have replaced the proven reserves that we sold into our produced. As you can see, the value of the Encore assets we acquired are getting better and better as evidenced by our new estimate of the Bakken oil potential.
I might remind you that we didn’t pay much for that upside or non-proved reserves in our Encore transaction, and the fact that we’ve just added over 15 million BOEs of proven reserves in the Bakken, 12 million BOEs in the Haynesville, and now projected we could have up to 350 million BOEs of total Bakken potential, that’s up from Encore’s estimate of approximately 100 million barrels, illustrates the quality of the assets we acquired and, if you will, that the acquisition was a good deal.
The sale of the acquired southern Encore assets for $900 million was also a good value and also concluded sooner than expected. The point I am making is I want to reinforce what several of our shareholders are beginning to realize and that is the Encore acquisition was a good deal for us.
The other guys will walk you through the numbers and give you more details on this quarter’s news, but I think one of the things I am most proud of is that we maintained or exceeded our forecast in budgets during a time when there was an extra strain on our entire organization.
During the last several months, we have been actively moving forward, integrating Encore’s assets, systems, and personnel and we are far from done, but thanks to the diligent efforts of our employees all these extra work has not reduced the quality of our core operations and that is something I think all of us at Denbury can be proud of.
I think Tracy may give you a little update on divestitures, but we are about to send out a set of repackaged Haynesville assets. We have broken it up into smaller pieces, which we hope will be more attracted to the other operators by allowing them to limit the amount of non-operated interests they would be acquiring.
We are also marketing some other minor properties we acquired in the Encore acquisition, and our review of strategic alternatives for ENP is still ongoing. The ENP process has taken a bit longer than expected as we have been focused on a potential transaction on Elk Basin, one of the Rocky Mountain properties that we would like to flood with CO2 someday.
We are hopeful that we would be able to close on enough additional asset sales to fund the projected 2010 cash flow deficit as we are spending a bit more than we are making. If we accomplish this goal we will leave 2010 with very little or no bank debt, unless of course we buy something else. That would give us about $1.6 billion of dry powder for the future.
If these divestitures don’t materialize or close this year, we will simply dip into our almost unused bank credit line. Bottom line there are a lot of good things happening here at Denbury, the oil prices are even cooperating, most recently back in the low 80s in spite of a lethargic economy. It is definitely a good time to be an oil-focused independent.
Now let’s move on to details, Mark will give you a review of the financials.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phil. As reported in our press release, Denbury had net income for the second quarter of $135.4 million, $0.34 per basic common share. However, net income adjusted to exclude fair value hedging changes, the Encore merger-related costs, and the
componenttext:
Thank you, Phil. As reported in our press release, Denbury had net income for the second quarter of $135.4 million, $0.34 per basic common share. However, net income adjusted to exclude fair value hedging changes, the Encore merger-related costs, and the impact from a change in our tax rate as a result of the southern asset sale was $72.9 million or $0.18 per share.
As we’ve typically done, I’ll primarily focus on the sequential results of the first and second quarters of 2010. During the second quarter of 2010, our tertiary production was 28,507 barrels per day, 5% higher than our Q1 tertiary production.
On a pro forma basis, excluding the production associated with the southern property sale and assuming the acquired Encore properties had been included in our first quarter results for the entire quarter, our overall production increased 5% sequentially to 78,545 BOEs per day in Q2 as compared to 74,489 BOEs per day in Q1. That increased primarily due to our tertiary Bakken and Haynesville production.
As previously discussed in our analyst conference a couple of months ago, our forecasted production for 2010 excluding the divested southern assets for the entire year was estimated at 76,650 BOEs per day.
With the increase in our tertiary production forecast from 27,750 barrels per day to 28,000 barrels per day, and a 5% increase in our Bakken production estimate to an average of 4,600 BOEs per day and a couple other minor changes, we are now increasing our pro forma 2010 production guidance excluding the southern assets to 77,000 BOEs per day.
Our average oil price received for the quarter including derivative settlements was $71.68 per barrel in Q2, as compared to $60.60 per barrel in Q1, but if derivative settlements are excluded our average oil price received for the second quarter was $73.99 per barrel as compared to $76.53 per barrel in Q1.
Our NYMEX oil price differential was $4.13 per barrel below NYMEX in the second quarter as compared to $2.08 per barrel below NYMEX in Q1, due primarily to the acquired Encore properties which typically have higher differentials. Assuming we had included Encore’s production for the entire first quarter, our NYMEX differential would have been $3.77 per barrel below NYMEX in Q1.
Differentials in our northern properties were negatively impacted during one month in the second quarter as a result of a temporary refinery shutdown. Our lease operating expense increased by $31.5 million from the first quarter, but on a per BOE basis, our overall lease operating costs were down from $20.12 per BOE in Q1 to $16.69 per BOE in Q2, primarily due to increased production, and addition of the Encore properties in our results for the full quarter and lower tertiary production costs primarily due to decrease in work over expenses.
If the southern property sales have been excluded from our results for the entire quarter, our LOE per BOE would have been approximately $17.12 per BOE in Q2 as compared to $18.69 per BOE in Q1. I would expect our LOE per BOE to be between these two numbers for the remainder of 2010, but favoring a number on the higher side for the rest of the year.
G&A expenses decreased by $1.5 million from Q1, even though the first quarter only included Encore for a partial period. The decrease between the quarters is due to the higher cost in Q1 associated with bonus and equity compensation, EOR related cost, cost associated with the sale of Genesis and higher overhead recoveries in Q2 related in part to our continued operating of the southern properties that we sold in mid-May.
Going forward, I would expect that our G&A will continue to increase as we add new employees throughout the year. Going forward, I’d expect our G&A per BOE to be more in line with our six-month average in the low-to-mid $5 per BOE range, but this could deviate somewhat.
We’ll continue to have ongoing merger-related cost associated with integration and severance, but we anticipate this amount will reduce significantly going forward to be more in the range of possibly $6 million or $7 million in the third quarter and $3 million to $4 million in the fourth quarter.
The vast majority of the expense in Q2 associated with severance-related costs as we’ve made significant progress with the integration of the Encore employees. Approximately $3.2 million of the Encore merger-related cost were non-cash expense associated with equity compensation for severed employees.
Interest expense, net of capitalized interest, increased sequentially from $26.4 million to $43.5 million, primarily related to incremental debt incurred to finance the Encore merger.
Average debt outstanding was $3.2 billion in Q2 as compared to $2.2 billion in Q1. Capitalized interest was $23.9 million this quarter as compared to $21.3 million last quarter, primarily due to incremental interest capitalized on the Green Pipeline.
Going forward, we expect our capitalized interest will decrease to around $10 million per quarter until the end of the year when we expect the rest of the Green Pipeline to be placed into service.
Our bank debt at June 30 was $40 million on a $1.6 billion credit line, as we have paid off most of our bank debt with proceeds from the southern property sale, and we had $245 million outstanding on ENP’s bank line. We also ended up with $2.176 billion of senior subordinated debt outstanding at a weighted average interest rate of approximately 8.5% after the completion of the tender offers for the Encore’s subordinated debt.
Based on our anticipated capital spending in excess of cash flows for 2010, we would expect to see our bank debt increase throughout the remainder of the year as we plan to outspend our cash flow by approximately $200 million to $300 million.
However, as Phil mentioned, if we are successful in closing on either the Haynesville sale or our ENP ownership the proceeds from either of these transactions would likely cover most of the deficit leaving us with little or no bank debt at year end.
Our debt-to-cap ratio at June 30 is a respectable 36%, and debt to estimated 2010 EBITDA would be in the mid 2 to 1 range going forward. We’re extremely pleased with our financial position, and the improvement of our leverage ratios set soon after the completion of the Encore acquisition.
Our capital expenditure budget for 2010 remains at $1.06 billion, excluding acquisitions and capitalized interest and net of approximately $50 million in anticipated sale leasebacks.
On a combined basis, the $1.06 billion would exceed our anticipated cash flows by approximately $200 million to $300 million, assuming 12 months of combined cash flow for the combined companies based on current commodity prices.
Our DD&A for the oil and gas properties decreased slightly on a per BOA basis from Q1 due primarily to the incremental proved reserves record in Q2, which Tracy will discuss more in a few minutes.
With regard to income taxes, we currently anticipate that we will able to deduct a large portion of our Green Pipeline that we put into service in mid-year when we begin injecting CO2 into Oyster Bayou. This should help to limit our current tax expense and help shield additional tax on asset dispositions.
As result of the sale of our southern properties in May, we’ve slightly lowered our statutory rate due to our mix of states and applied a new deferred tax rate to our deferred tax balance. In doing this, we decreased our deferred tax expense for the quarter and our effective rate. This should normalize to a rate around 39% going forward. However, future asset changes will also impact this rate.
With that, I’ll pass it to Tracy.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark. As we’ve reported in the press release, we added 65.4 million barrels or BOEs during the second quarter. The majority of these reserved additions were in our CO2 EOR projects at Delhi Field and our other CO2 projects.The largest reserve
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark. As we’ve reported in the press release, we added 65.4 million barrels or BOEs during the second quarter. The majority of these reserved additions were in our CO2 EOR projects at Delhi Field and our other CO2 projects.
The largest reserve estimate we added was at Delhi Field, where we added 30 million barrels of reserves based on observing a significant and sustained response to the CO2. As the past practices, our initial crude reserve bookings were approximately 75%, about 13% recovery factor what we ultimately expect to be able to recover from the field.
If you compare the 30 million barrels to our prior presentations, you’ll notice that the Delhi net potential number was only 33 million barrels on those prior presentations. In addition to the proved bookings at Delhi, we’ve also increased our total potential reserves in Delhi to 38 million barrels, which equates to a 17% recovery factor.
Additional proved reserves were also added in the Heidelberg CO2 project. These reserves were added in areas of the field that were not initially considered to be part of the floodable area. And then based on performance of our CO2 projects at Tinsley and Lockhart Crossing Fields, we added additional proved reserves there as well.
Based on performance, the recovery factors were increased from the original estimates of 13% on a proved basis to 17% as performances dictated. As additional areas of these fields respond and as other fields’ performance dictates, the reserves in these additional areas and other fields will be adjusted accordingly.
We have completed our review of our Bakken acreage position and have estimated that the total potential as proved, probable and possible net reserves to our interest is approximately 350 million BOEs. This potential includes reserves associated with over 2,850 potential locations. The former Encore estimate included only two wells per unit and included only one reservoir. The current estimate includes three wells per reservoir per unit.
A vast majority of these future locations in excess of 90% are estimated to be on 1,280 acre unit. Forecast of the initial 30 day rates varied from 300 to 500 BOEs per day for wells drilled on 640 acre units and 400 to 900 BOEs per day for wells drilled on 1,280 acre units.
The higher 30 day rates are estimated for locations that are within the Nesson Anticline line and the lower rates are estimated for areas that are not located within the Nesson.
Gross estimated reserves for each location vary from a low of just over 200 million BOEs for the Almond and Northeast Foothills area to a high of approximately 675 million BOEs for 1,280 acre unit locations within the Nesson Anticline.
As we have discussed in prior meetings and presentations, Encore had drilled a few unsuccessful wells in the Almond and Northeast Foothills areas, so we have not estimated any additional potential in acreage north or east of these wells. However, about 10% of our total Bakken potential still relates to this area as it could be productive and the industry is moving in this direction.
We continue to monitor all data that is made available within the Bakken area and we’ll continue to review and update the reserves associated with our Bakken position based on new information.
Based on our expected five operated rig program and an estimated 10 plus non-operated rig program, we expect our production rates in the Bakken to increase dramatically over the next 18 months.
Preliminarily, we are estimating our average 2011 net production rate to double our 2010 forecast and have a production rate of 4,600 BOEs per day. As we get greater clarity on other operators’ plans for 2011, we will be able to refine and report our estimated production rate for the Bakken and other properties.
Reserve additions in the Bakken during the second quarter were 15.2 million BOEs based on the results of ours and others drilling operations. This increase essentially doubled our proved reserves associated with our Bakken position. Based on our expected drilling plan over the next several years, we expect to continually add significant proved reserves within the Bakken.
The other area with significant reserve additions during the second quarter was our Haynesville area, where 12 million BOEs were added as a result of our drilling program during the year. While we have released our operated drilling rig there, there are still typically five to six non-operated rigs running in which we are participating.
We have yet to complete our remaining two operated wells that have been drilled and cased. We expect both of these wells to be completed by the end of the quarter and thus expect a production boost from these wells and other non-operated wells during the fourth quarter.
Finally, as Phil mentioned, I’ll give you a brief comment on our divesture efforts. We have closed, as we’ve announced on as August 1st transferred operatorship to Quantum for the assets involved in our southern asset divestiture.
We have begun marketing our remaining East Texas, North Louisiana, and Haynesville assets at this time and should have that out in the next few weeks. Assuming we receive an acceptable offer for these assets, closing is not expected until sometime in the fourth quarter.
We’re also marketing our Cleveland Sand Play in Northwest Oklahoma, which we acquired as part of the Encore acquisition. We’re expecting bids on the Cleveland Sand Play imminently and assuming we receive an acceptable offer, we would expect to close this sale during the third quarter. Assuming we are successful in all these divestiture efforts, we will have essentially completed our rationalization efforts outlined as part of the Encore acquisition strategy.
With that, I’ll turn it over to Bob to talk about operations.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thank you, Tracy. I’ll give you a quick update on the major CO2 EOR fields and some of Bakken activity that we had during the second quarter.Tertiary production averaged 28,507 net BOEs per day for the quarter. That’s an increase of 1,484 net B
componenttext:
Yes. Thank you, Tracy. I’ll give you a quick update on the major CO2 EOR fields and some of Bakken activity that we had during the second quarter.
Tertiary production averaged 28,507 net BOEs per day for the quarter. That’s an increase of 1,484 net BOEs or about 5% compared to the first quarter of 2010, and then based on this increase in tertiary production rates, we are raising our average daily tertiary production guidance to 28,000 net BOEs average for the year.
We currently have 14 different fields under CO2 injection in six of our eight phases of expansion. With this limited time provided, I can’t go over all of them in detail, but I will touch on the highlights of the major fields. But overall, we continue to have a great success in our CO2 operations, with four of our fields exhibiting double-digit production growth during this quarter.
Phase 1 fields consisting of the six field areas in Southwest Mississippi increased by 382 BOEs per day or 3% increase over the first quarter, with an average daily rate of 12,347 net BOEs per day. The Little Creek area, the most matured area we operate, had a second quarter of double-digit growth.
The field averaged 1,971 net BOEs per day during the quarter, that’s a16.6% increase over the prior quarter. The increase was primarily due to response from a long-term non-responding wells and result of the WAG which is a Water Alternating Gas injection test that performed much better than expected.
During the quarter, this WAG program was expanded to two more Little Creek patterns in a high recovery area to test the potential of additional reserve recovery using this method.
At Brookhaven Field, we also established a four-patterned WAG program during May in our area that needs improvement. We are optimizing additional oil production; we will establish WAG in that area, we’d hope to see production by year end.
At McComb Smithdale, we decreased production by 129 net BOEs per day on a quarter-to-quarter basis, but at McComb, we have four wells that were drilled in the expansion area. They are being completed now. These wells should hopefully help us out, as we go through the year, to have positive impact on our production rates.
In the Mallalieu area, we increased production by 185 net BOEs or 5 percentage quarter-to-quarter, and at Lockhart Crossing, it continues to perform better than forecasted with the production growth of 16% plus quarter-to-quarter. Impact from five new wells should allow Lockhart Crossing to continue to increase further during the third and the fourth quarters of 2010.
Phase II experienced a 187 net barrel reduction in rate as compared to the first quarter; however, Heidelberg, about a 149 net BOEs per day increased 8.7% on a quarter-to-quarter basis. Our operational team continues to aggressively expand Heidelberg flood and expect to complete additional well sites and placed over 20 wells on line during the third quarter of this year.
Eucutta experienced 168 net BOE per day decrease. Eucutta is essentially fully developed, so we will continue to exhibit a decline. On a quarter-to-quarter basis, Soso Field was flat to last quarter and isn’t expected to change much for the rest of the year.
Martinville is where the smaller floods in Phase 2 has fluctuated up and down over the last couple of years, it decreased to 163 barrels per day in the second quarter.
For those of you that follow Denbury closely, you know that our Phase 3 EOR CO2 area is Tinsley Field. This reservoir continues to perform better than predicted. Tinsley Field increased 829 net BOEs per day, almost 19% quarter-to-quarter with a second quarter average production rate of 5,248 BOEs per day.
The addition of six wells in the Unit C’s [ph] fault block, there in the quarter along with other responding wells made the third consecutive quarter production increases with double digits.
Tinsley was aggressively expanded during 2009 and we continue to increase well count and our proved facility this year. We plan to invest in excess of $50 million into the Tinsley project during 2010.
Phase 4 is Cranfield, production decreased slightly, 125 net BOEs per day quarter-to-quarter. The decline is partly due to delay in our drilling program. The drilling rig we had under contract we used to develop other Denbury tertiary field during the first and second quarters, but the rig has now returned to Cranfield and it’s now in operations. We will drill and complete the 12 wells 2010 capital drilling program during the third and fourth quarters of this year.
At Delhi, which is our Phase 5, CO2 expansion continues in the (inaudible) Tuscaloosa formations. Purchased CO2 injection increased to an average 84 million cubic feet a day during the quarter. As the reservoir pressure increases, additional oil response is expected during the year.
Second quarter average production was 648 net BOEs per day, that’s up from 63 BOEs per day during the first quarter. The EOR production continues to run above forecast as a result of earlier than expected response and then currently 16 wells are flowing into the production system at various flow rates and oil rates, and we have completed our 20 well 2010 drilling program and we’ll continue to expand the facilities there at Delhi.
Phases 7 and 8 are the Hastings and Oyster Bayou Field respectively, those filed of course are located along the Texas Gulf Coast. Progress in both fields is moving forward and on schedule. Oyster Bayou began injection on June 29. The current injection rate is approximately 44 million cubic feet a day at the three wells. And the first EOR production there is not expected until the second half of 2011.
Development continues with three capital rigs at Oyster Bayou along with the construction of our production and compression facilities. Hastings, we are running five capital rigs there, with current existing wells for CO2 injection, sometime early 2011 or late this year.
Jackson Dome, we need to talk about, our average production was 768 million cubic feet a day during the second quarter, that’s slightly ahead of our forecasted CO2 volumes. The drydock well, which is the Denbury 2916 #1 will be tested in the next few weeks, and this well should be placed in production during late 2010 or early 2011.
Currently, we also have two drilling rigs operated in the Gluckstadt field, which will increase our CO2 production levels later in 2010 or possibly 2011. These wells could also improve or increase our proved reserve if the field is found to have multiple fault blocks or separate compartments. Additional CO2 production from these wells will ensure that we have the deliverability to continue our field expansions along the Gulf Coast and Mississippi.
The 24-inch Green Pipeline construction was completed at the Oyster Bayou field late last year, and the first 260 miles were successfully packed and commissioned and is now transporting about 44 million cubic feet a day into Oyster Bayou. Now we have three remaining segments of the pipeline and those should be completed late this year to the Hastings field.
We have 19 miles from Oyster Bayou to the east side of Galveston Bay, and that will be hydrostatic tested either late August or the first week of September. The 14 miles of Galveston Bay crossing is underway, we have several miles of pipeline already constructed and we’ve already completed the drill on the Houston ship channel.
And then we have the remaining 25 miles on the west side of Galveston Bay, that’s underway. We have about 30% of the pipeline welled in. Like I said, our goal is to have the Green Pipeline in service to Hastings by year end or early 2011.
Moving from the Gulf Coast to Rocky Mountains, our 20 inch Green core pipeline is a 230 mile pipeline running from Lost Cabin, Wyoming up to Bell Creek, Montana. Right of ways in survey are undergoing with 95% of the surveys complete and about 41 of the right of way has been acquired.
We have preliminary engineering, it’s completed, finalizing the design pipe specifications. We work on the environmental assessment and the project should have a target start date of August 2011.
Bell Creek flood in Montana will be the first Rocky Mountain Denbury EOR flood, and we are right now recompleting idle water injection wells to CO2 service. Thus far 17 wells have been prepared for CO2 injection. We expect to have an additional 12 injection wells completed by the year end. That project start date will be sometime late 2012 or early 2013.
Mark mentioned lease operating expenses from the combined company. They decreased on a unit basis from $20.12 of BOE during the first quarter to $16.69 BOEs in second quarter. As we go through the year, we expect them to average slightly above $18 per BOE and we hope to maintain that expense rate.
If you look back and review the legacy Denbury lease operating expenses, they decreased 2% or $0.51 net BOE quarter-to-quarter from $22.86 in net BOE to $22.35 in net BOE. Electrical and fuel cost decreased, mostly that was 3.9%. Work-over cost also decreased 21%, primarily due to the operational improvements and procedures that we’ve instituted related to remedial work on the CO2 injection wells.
Contract labor did increase 22% due to capital activity and the contracting plan op raise during our expansions and startups. We continue to review our LOE cost, like changes to our process and procedures to hopefully maintain those levels.
Moving to the Williston Basin, North Dakota, we currently have three rigs working the Bakken formation. We contracted a fourth rig to commence drilling operations during September of 2010. Our fifth drilling rig is also planned to start drilling operations in the first quarter of 2011.
We have completed five Bakken wells to date and another three are in the process of being completed. One thing that we commonly do with the method of evaluating reserves potential is to just look at the average production rates for the first 30, 60, 90 days of production. The majority of our wells show pretty good response.
Early on, we completed Porcupine wells in March. We had one well that is the Sanish well on 640 acre, 12 stage frac. The 60-day average there was about 385 BOEs per day and the Porcupine also a Bakken well 640 acre, 12 stage at an average rate of over 498 BOEs per day for 60-day average.
The Werre Trust, another well in the Sanish area, which was 1280 acre, 19 stage, had a 60-day average of over 900 barrels oil per day. And then the last two that we have 60-day averages on are the Swenson, Charlson, Bakken completion 640 acre, 12 stage.
That well had a 60-day average of 873 BOEs per day and our Gilbertson, Charlson, Bakken well again a 640 acre, 12 stage at 619 average BOEs per day. I think Mark is going to put this information out on our web page in the next 24 to 48 hours.
Partly the Haynesville, Denbury has drilled three operating wells during 2010. Although we have ceased drilling operations and released our drilling rig there we are continuing to participate in wells operated by Chesapeake, JW, Blackhawk, Chemtura, El Paso, (inaudible) and to-date Denbury has participated in gross 23 wells during the year and expected to participate in additional nine gross wells AP [ph] by these operators.
Haynesville production in the second quarter averaged 3931 net BOEs per day. Production expected to fluctuate in the Haynesville depending on the timing of these completions, but we have two remaining wells Denbury operated that will be fraced before the end of the third quarter and that should also add to our rate during the third quarter.
With that, I’ll return it to Phil.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, guys. That’s all good news. As Bob mentioned, we will have update our presentation on the Web site probably the next day or two that will have the updated guidance by area, the Bakken results you just referred to, the wells that are drilling, th
componenttext:
Thanks, guys. That’s all good news. As Bob mentioned, we will have update our presentation on the Web site probably the next day or two that will have the updated guidance by area, the Bakken results you just referred to, the wells that are drilling, the updated Bakken potential, et cetera. So in case you missed some of those numbers, you can refer to our Web site shortly.
So that’s all good news for Denbury, let’s turn now to ENP, I’ve already kind of mentioned that the ENP strategic process is ongoing and it’s taken a bit long than we expected because we’ve been focused on the transaction at Elk Basin, but Mark will give you a brief update on the ENP numbers.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: As announced last week, ENP’s distribution for the second quarter of 2010 was proved at $0.50 per unit, same distribution rate as Q1. Cash available for distribution in Q2 was $25 million as compared to $27.9 million in Q1, lower due primarily to lower
componenttext:
As announced last week, ENP’s distribution for the second quarter of 2010 was proved at $0.50 per unit, same distribution rate as Q1. Cash available for distribution in Q2 was $25 million as compared to $27.9 million in Q1, lower due primarily to lower production, price realization, and incremental G&A expense of $1 million associated with the hiring of investment advisor by the Conflicts Committee of the Board of Directors.
Our coverage ratio for the first quarter was just under 1.1 times. Production for the second quarter totaled 8,841 BOEs per day as compared to 9,034 BOEs per day in the first quarter of 2010. Going forward, we expect our production to continue to be on a gradual decline for the remainder of 2010. We repaid $5 million in bank debt during the quarter, bringing our bank debt to $245 million at June 30.
With that, I’ll turn it back to Phil.

componenttext: We’re pretty much using a tight decline for the reserves based on the 30-day average. So we use a (inaudible) point of 1.6 and final decline rate of about 8%. componenttext: To hold all the operated units that we’re forecasting, it’s five. That’s what we’ve scheduled out and that’s through 2011. headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Following up on a few Bakken questions. Can you talk about the completion techniques you guys are using there? Are you doing plug-and-perf or sliding sleeve?
componenttext: Following up on a few Bakken questions. Can you talk about the completion techniques you guys are using there? Are you doing plug-and-perf or sliding sleeve?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: No. We’re trying to standardize that. We’re going to use ball/sleeve method. The plug-and-perf, we’ve had some complications with the wireline, so we’re finding ball/sleeve is probably the most cost effective and expeditious to your stimulation ti
componenttext: No. We’re trying to standardize that. We’re going to use ball/sleeve method. The plug-and-perf, we’ve had some complications with the wireline, so we’re finding ball/sleeve is probably the most cost effective and expeditious to your stimulation timing and removes need for that wireline. So we’re using that method.

componenttext: Well, I mean, it’s down to 3P, number one, so, I mean, generally, the one offset is proved and the third offset is either possible to bring on how it’s spaced. I mean, that’s just based on what you’re recovering today as the individual wells and you look at the amount of oil in place across a section or a unit. It looks like it’s going to take at least three wells to get a reasonable recovery.

componenttext: I guess, we are going to see uplifts in Tinsley, Heidelberg, Delhi, and probably Lockhart Crossing, we just said we have five wells we’re going to put in there and may be some at McComb, Smithdale probably flat to increasing, but I think you have to remember that Mallalieu is a mature field, Eucutta is a mature field and Brookhaven are all fairly large mature fields. And so you might see a little bit of run-off. Though it’s not an exaggerated run-off, but some run-off, in 2% to 3% I think is what we saw quart-to-quarter.

componenttext: A few things, if you recall, Noel, kind of like stair step or wherever you tend to get a bump and then you get flat a little bit and then you get bump, and so we just expect third quarter to be relatively flat to second. headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Tracy, there is a few questions on Oyster Bayou. I was wondering if you could describe the sort of rock properties there, how they might differ from some of the fields you’ve flooded prior to this? Is there any reason to believe you might get a faster r
componenttext: Tracy, there is a few questions on Oyster Bayou. I was wondering if you could describe the sort of rock properties there, how they might differ from some of the fields you’ve flooded prior to this? Is there any reason to believe you might get a faster response there, and also just the estimate of reserves there?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: The reservoir other than being higher permeability, it’s really not much different than most of the other reservoirs we have, everything we have in the Gulf Coast is a sandstone. But as far as faster response, I mean, the real issue there, Eric, is the
componenttext:
The reservoir other than being higher permeability, it’s really not much different than most of the other reservoirs we have, everything we have in the Gulf Coast is a sandstone. But as far as faster response, I mean, the real issue there, Eric, is the fact that the reservoir is very depleted. We’re looking at a minimum of a year to pressurize the reservoir up in order for it to respond. So our historical has been six months to nine months from first injection. So that’s on the long side of that.
I think, once we get it to pressure, I think with the permeability we can see some pretty good rates, but as far as being early I don’t think you’ll see that. And then the reserves in Oyster Bayou are, the majority of that 25 million barrels to 30 million barrels that we’re having to see reach complex. I think, it’s two to three (inaudible) or something like that.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: So you probably don’t book any of those until maybe 2012, late 2011. Is that a fair assumption?
componenttext: So you probably don’t book any of those until maybe 2012, late 2011. Is that a fair assumption?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. We’re hoping for late 2011, but just depending on when we actually get a significant response will be when we actually book it.
componenttext: Yes. We’re hoping for late 2011, but just depending on when we actually get a significant response will be when we actually book it.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: The second one was on Elk Basin. Kind of what’s the rationale for carving that out? Is there a plan to develop it, just some more detail on that would be helpful?
componenttext: The second one was on Elk Basin. Kind of what’s the rationale for carving that out? Is there a plan to develop it, just some more detail on that would be helpful?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Elk Basin is a massive formation within our basin is a perspective CO2 flood. It has over 500 million, 600 million barrels originally in place, it has performed very well. So that’s a rationale to keeping that out. At least we’re taking the CO2 upside
componenttext: Elk Basin is a massive formation within our basin is a perspective CO2 flood. It has over 500 million, 600 million barrels originally in place, it has performed very well. So that’s a rationale to keeping that out. At least we’re taking the CO2 upside at Elk Basin within Denbury. It would be very difficult for ENP ever to achieve the CO2 upside because honestly they just won’t have the capital, but that’s the idea is keep the CO2 upside at Denbury.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010

componenttext: But what is it? Green Zone pipeline or the...

componenttext: It would say we’d require another pipeline.

componenttextpreview: It’s kind of up by itself a little bit in Northwest Wyoming. So, it is, we will probably, we will do Bell Creek obviously first in CCA before we go in that direction. So it’s ways out in the future anyway.
componenttext: It’s kind of up by itself a little bit in Northwest Wyoming. So, it is, we will probably, we will do Bell Creek obviously first in CCA before we go in that direction. So it’s ways out in the future anyway.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010

componenttext: The next question is from Nicholas Pope of Dahlman Rose. Please go ahead.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: I think you have given like some bits and pieces of 2011 and 2012 expectations for CapEx. I was hoping maybe you could just kind of round that out a little bit, maybe, where your expectations are relative to what you are expecting kind of cash flows to be
componenttext: I think you have given like some bits and pieces of 2011 and 2012 expectations for CapEx. I was hoping maybe you could just kind of round that out a little bit, maybe, where your expectations are relative to what you are expecting kind of cash flows to be? What the split is going to be between pipelines and ENP?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we have given bits and pieces, it’s hard because we don’t have our 2011 capital budget then, precisely, but preliminarily, I think you can take our slide show and that pie chart that we have for 2010, I don’t think it’s going to change too m
componenttext:
Well, we have given bits and pieces, it’s hard because we don’t have our 2011 capital budget then, precisely, but preliminarily, I think you can take our slide show and that pie chart that we have for 2010, I don’t think it’s going to change too much in 2011. Pipelines are still going to be somewhere in that 200 range; instead of the Green Pipeline it’s going to be the Greencore.
What you’ll probably see depending on what happens with the sale of Haynesville, the Haynesville number could go away completely or at least go down and maybe a little bit, but you’re going to spend a little bit more in the Bakken because we’re going to add rigs.
So, I mean that’s kind of the high level, but the conceptual deal is just we haven’t given precise numbers. That depending on prices may still be a little bit above our cash flow, but it’s obviously, much less, and we expect it to be less than this year just because we expect some production increases. 2012 that’s a little further out, but I don’t think conceptually that will be too much different either. So I think you’ll see a budget over $1 billion plus or minus, maybe 10% or something near 15% and the allocation somewhat similar.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010

componenttext: Well, we kind of said, we’re not going to comment too much and so all we can say is it is still ongoing. But the main reason it has taken a little bit longer, as I mentioned in the previous day, was we’ve been working on a transaction with Elk Basin and trying to make that advantageous to all and that has just taken a little bit more time than we probably had originally thought.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, everybody. We’re excited about this quarter and a lot of good news hopefully that’s all coming through. Later this month, just to give you an update, we will be presenting the Intercom Conference in Denver, that’s just a couple weeks off and
componenttext: Thanks, everybody. We’re excited about this quarter and a lot of good news hopefully that’s all coming through. Later this month, just to give you an update, we will be presenting the Intercom Conference in Denver, that’s just a couple weeks off and the next probably big conference will be the Barclays Conference in New York in mid-September. We usually try to schedule meetings around these conferences. So, if some of you are interested, please contact Laurie Burkes, our IR Manager, and she’ll try to work those in. But I guess bottom-line is stay tuned, 2010 is looking good for Denbury, and so we expect some more positive things later this year. We’ll talk to you again soon. Thank you.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning and welcome to the Denbury Resources second quarter 2010 earnings release. All participants will be in a listen-only mode. After today’s presentation, there will be an opportunity to ask questions. Please note this event is being recorded.
componenttext:
Good morning and welcome to the Denbury Resources second quarter 2010 earnings release. All participants will be in a listen-only mode. After today’s presentation, there will be an opportunity to ask questions. Please note this event is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Phil Rykhoek. Please go ahead.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome everybody to Denbury and ENP second quarter conference call. Similar to last time, we plan to talk about Denbury first, then we’ll follow with an update on ENP and then open it up for questions.With me today, I have Tracy Evans, our
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome everybody to Denbury and ENP second quarter conference call. Similar to last time, we plan to talk about Denbury first, then we’ll follow with an update on ENP and then open it up for questions.
With me today, I have Tracy Evans, our President and COO; Mark Allen, our Senior VP and CFO; and Bob Cornelius, our Senior VP of Operations.
As you can see, things at Denbury are continuing to go well. As we highlighted in the press release, our production is ahead of forecast, expenses are on track or below and that’s always a nice combination which allowed us to beat the First Call earnings expectations by a few pennies.
Further, as you may notice, a significant portion of the green pipeline is now in service. We are also quite proud that we have replaced the proven reserves that we sold into our produced. As you can see, the value of the Encore assets we acquired are getting better and better as evidenced by our new estimate of the Bakken oil potential.
I might remind you that we didn’t pay much for that upside or non-proved reserves in our Encore transaction, and the fact that we’ve just added over 15 million BOEs of proven reserves in the Bakken, 12 million BOEs in the Haynesville, and now projected we could have up to 350 million BOEs of total Bakken potential, that’s up from Encore’s estimate of approximately 100 million barrels, illustrates the quality of the assets we acquired and, if you will, that the acquisition was a good deal.
The sale of the acquired southern Encore assets for $900 million was also a good value and also concluded sooner than expected. The point I am making is I want to reinforce what several of our shareholders are beginning to realize and that is the Encore acquisition was a good deal for us.
The other guys will walk you through the numbers and give you more details on this quarter’s news, but I think one of the things I am most proud of is that we maintained or exceeded our forecast in budgets during a time when there was an extra strain on our entire organization.
During the last several months, we have been actively moving forward, integrating Encore’s assets, systems, and personnel and we are far from done, but thanks to the diligent efforts of our employees all these extra work has not reduced the quality of our core operations and that is something I think all of us at Denbury can be proud of.
I think Tracy may give you a little update on divestitures, but we are about to send out a set of repackaged Haynesville assets. We have broken it up into smaller pieces, which we hope will be more attracted to the other operators by allowing them to limit the amount of non-operated interests they would be acquiring.
We are also marketing some other minor properties we acquired in the Encore acquisition, and our review of strategic alternatives for ENP is still ongoing. The ENP process has taken a bit longer than expected as we have been focused on a potential transaction on Elk Basin, one of the Rocky Mountain properties that we would like to flood with CO2 someday.
We are hopeful that we would be able to close on enough additional asset sales to fund the projected 2010 cash flow deficit as we are spending a bit more than we are making. If we accomplish this goal we will leave 2010 with very little or no bank debt, unless of course we buy something else. That would give us about $1.6 billion of dry powder for the future.
If these divestitures don’t materialize or close this year, we will simply dip into our almost unused bank credit line. Bottom line there are a lot of good things happening here at Denbury, the oil prices are even cooperating, most recently back in the low 80s in spite of a lethargic economy. It is definitely a good time to be an oil-focused independent.
Now let’s move on to details, Mark will give you a review of the financials.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phil. As reported in our press release, Denbury had net income for the second quarter of $135.4 million, $0.34 per basic common share. However, net income adjusted to exclude fair value hedging changes, the Encore merger-related costs, and the
componenttext:
Thank you, Phil. As reported in our press release, Denbury had net income for the second quarter of $135.4 million, $0.34 per basic common share. However, net income adjusted to exclude fair value hedging changes, the Encore merger-related costs, and the impact from a change in our tax rate as a result of the southern asset sale was $72.9 million or $0.18 per share.
As we’ve typically done, I’ll primarily focus on the sequential results of the first and second quarters of 2010. During the second quarter of 2010, our tertiary production was 28,507 barrels per day, 5% higher than our Q1 tertiary production.
On a pro forma basis, excluding the production associated with the southern property sale and assuming the acquired Encore properties had been included in our first quarter results for the entire quarter, our overall production increased 5% sequentially to 78,545 BOEs per day in Q2 as compared to 74,489 BOEs per day in Q1. That increased primarily due to our tertiary Bakken and Haynesville production.
As previously discussed in our analyst conference a couple of months ago, our forecasted production for 2010 excluding the divested southern assets for the entire year was estimated at 76,650 BOEs per day.
With the increase in our tertiary production forecast from 27,750 barrels per day to 28,000 barrels per day, and a 5% increase in our Bakken production estimate to an average of 4,600 BOEs per day and a couple other minor changes, we are now increasing our pro forma 2010 production guidance excluding the southern assets to 77,000 BOEs per day.
Our average oil price received for the quarter including derivative settlements was $71.68 per barrel in Q2, as compared to $60.60 per barrel in Q1, but if derivative settlements are excluded our average oil price received for the second quarter was $73.99 per barrel as compared to $76.53 per barrel in Q1.
Our NYMEX oil price differential was $4.13 per barrel below NYMEX in the second quarter as compared to $2.08 per barrel below NYMEX in Q1, due primarily to the acquired Encore properties which typically have higher differentials. Assuming we had included Encore’s production for the entire first quarter, our NYMEX differential would have been $3.77 per barrel below NYMEX in Q1.
Differentials in our northern properties were negatively impacted during one month in the second quarter as a result of a temporary refinery shutdown. Our lease operating expense increased by $31.5 million from the first quarter, but on a per BOE basis, our overall lease operating costs were down from $20.12 per BOE in Q1 to $16.69 per BOE in Q2, primarily due to increased production, and addition of the Encore properties in our results for the full quarter and lower tertiary production costs primarily due to decrease in work over expenses.
If the southern property sales have been excluded from our results for the entire quarter, our LOE per BOE would have been approximately $17.12 per BOE in Q2 as compared to $18.69 per BOE in Q1. I would expect our LOE per BOE to be between these two numbers for the remainder of 2010, but favoring a number on the higher side for the rest of the year.
G&A expenses decreased by $1.5 million from Q1, even though the first quarter only included Encore for a partial period. The decrease between the quarters is due to the higher cost in Q1 associated with bonus and equity compensation, EOR related cost, cost associated with the sale of Genesis and higher overhead recoveries in Q2 related in part to our continued operating of the southern properties that we sold in mid-May.
Going forward, I would expect that our G&A will continue to increase as we add new employees throughout the year. Going forward, I’d expect our G&A per BOE to be more in line with our six-month average in the low-to-mid $5 per BOE range, but this could deviate somewhat.
We’ll continue to have ongoing merger-related cost associated with integration and severance, but we anticipate this amount will reduce significantly going forward to be more in the range of possibly $6 million or $7 million in the third quarter and $3 million to $4 million in the fourth quarter.
The vast majority of the expense in Q2 associated with severance-related costs as we’ve made significant progress with the integration of the Encore employees. Approximately $3.2 million of the Encore merger-related cost were non-cash expense associated with equity compensation for severed employees.
Interest expense, net of capitalized interest, increased sequentially from $26.4 million to $43.5 million, primarily related to incremental debt incurred to finance the Encore merger.
Average debt outstanding was $3.2 billion in Q2 as compared to $2.2 billion in Q1. Capitalized interest was $23.9 million this quarter as compared to $21.3 million last quarter, primarily due to incremental interest capitalized on the Green Pipeline.
Going forward, we expect our capitalized interest will decrease to around $10 million per quarter until the end of the year when we expect the rest of the Green Pipeline to be placed into service.
Our bank debt at June 30 was $40 million on a $1.6 billion credit line, as we have paid off most of our bank debt with proceeds from the southern property sale, and we had $245 million outstanding on ENP’s bank line. We also ended up with $2.176 billion of senior subordinated debt outstanding at a weighted average interest rate of approximately 8.5% after the completion of the tender offers for the Encore’s subordinated debt.
Based on our anticipated capital spending in excess of cash flows for 2010, we would expect to see our bank debt increase throughout the remainder of the year as we plan to outspend our cash flow by approximately $200 million to $300 million.
However, as Phil mentioned, if we are successful in closing on either the Haynesville sale or our ENP ownership the proceeds from either of these transactions would likely cover most of the deficit leaving us with little or no bank debt at year end.
Our debt-to-cap ratio at June 30 is a respectable 36%, and debt to estimated 2010 EBITDA would be in the mid 2 to 1 range going forward. We’re extremely pleased with our financial position, and the improvement of our leverage ratios set soon after the completion of the Encore acquisition.
Our capital expenditure budget for 2010 remains at $1.06 billion, excluding acquisitions and capitalized interest and net of approximately $50 million in anticipated sale leasebacks.
On a combined basis, the $1.06 billion would exceed our anticipated cash flows by approximately $200 million to $300 million, assuming 12 months of combined cash flow for the combined companies based on current commodity prices.
Our DD&A for the oil and gas properties decreased slightly on a per BOA basis from Q1 due primarily to the incremental proved reserves record in Q2, which Tracy will discuss more in a few minutes.
With regard to income taxes, we currently anticipate that we will able to deduct a large portion of our Green Pipeline that we put into service in mid-year when we begin injecting CO2 into Oyster Bayou. This should help to limit our current tax expense and help shield additional tax on asset dispositions.
As result of the sale of our southern properties in May, we’ve slightly lowered our statutory rate due to our mix of states and applied a new deferred tax rate to our deferred tax balance. In doing this, we decreased our deferred tax expense for the quarter and our effective rate. This should normalize to a rate around 39% going forward. However, future asset changes will also impact this rate.
With that, I’ll pass it to Tracy.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark. As we’ve reported in the press release, we added 65.4 million barrels or BOEs during the second quarter. The majority of these reserved additions were in our CO2 EOR projects at Delhi Field and our other CO2 projects.The largest reserve
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark. As we’ve reported in the press release, we added 65.4 million barrels or BOEs during the second quarter. The majority of these reserved additions were in our CO2 EOR projects at Delhi Field and our other CO2 projects.
The largest reserve estimate we added was at Delhi Field, where we added 30 million barrels of reserves based on observing a significant and sustained response to the CO2. As the past practices, our initial crude reserve bookings were approximately 75%, about 13% recovery factor what we ultimately expect to be able to recover from the field.
If you compare the 30 million barrels to our prior presentations, you’ll notice that the Delhi net potential number was only 33 million barrels on those prior presentations. In addition to the proved bookings at Delhi, we’ve also increased our total potential reserves in Delhi to 38 million barrels, which equates to a 17% recovery factor.
Additional proved reserves were also added in the Heidelberg CO2 project. These reserves were added in areas of the field that were not initially considered to be part of the floodable area. And then based on performance of our CO2 projects at Tinsley and Lockhart Crossing Fields, we added additional proved reserves there as well.
Based on performance, the recovery factors were increased from the original estimates of 13% on a proved basis to 17% as performances dictated. As additional areas of these fields respond and as other fields’ performance dictates, the reserves in these additional areas and other fields will be adjusted accordingly.
We have completed our review of our Bakken acreage position and have estimated that the total potential as proved, probable and possible net reserves to our interest is approximately 350 million BOEs. This potential includes reserves associated with over 2,850 potential locations. The former Encore estimate included only two wells per unit and included only one reservoir. The current estimate includes three wells per reservoir per unit.
A vast majority of these future locations in excess of 90% are estimated to be on 1,280 acre unit. Forecast of the initial 30 day rates varied from 300 to 500 BOEs per day for wells drilled on 640 acre units and 400 to 900 BOEs per day for wells drilled on 1,280 acre units.
The higher 30 day rates are estimated for locations that are within the Nesson Anticline line and the lower rates are estimated for areas that are not located within the Nesson.
Gross estimated reserves for each location vary from a low of just over 200 million BOEs for the Almond and Northeast Foothills area to a high of approximately 675 million BOEs for 1,280 acre unit locations within the Nesson Anticline.
As we have discussed in prior meetings and presentations, Encore had drilled a few unsuccessful wells in the Almond and Northeast Foothills areas, so we have not estimated any additional potential in acreage north or east of these wells. However, about 10% of our total Bakken potential still relates to this area as it could be productive and the industry is moving in this direction.
We continue to monitor all data that is made available within the Bakken area and we’ll continue to review and update the reserves associated with our Bakken position based on new information.
Based on our expected five operated rig program and an estimated 10 plus non-operated rig program, we expect our production rates in the Bakken to increase dramatically over the next 18 months.
Preliminarily, we are estimating our average 2011 net production rate to double our 2010 forecast and have a production rate of 4,600 BOEs per day. As we get greater clarity on other operators’ plans for 2011, we will be able to refine and report our estimated production rate for the Bakken and other properties.
Reserve additions in the Bakken during the second quarter were 15.2 million BOEs based on the results of ours and others drilling operations. This increase essentially doubled our proved reserves associated with our Bakken position. Based on our expected drilling plan over the next several years, we expect to continually add significant proved reserves within the Bakken.
The other area with significant reserve additions during the second quarter was our Haynesville area, where 12 million BOEs were added as a result of our drilling program during the year. While we have released our operated drilling rig there, there are still typically five to six non-operated rigs running in which we are participating.
We have yet to complete our remaining two operated wells that have been drilled and cased. We expect both of these wells to be completed by the end of the quarter and thus expect a production boost from these wells and other non-operated wells during the fourth quarter.
Finally, as Phil mentioned, I’ll give you a brief comment on our divesture efforts. We have closed, as we’ve announced on as August 1st transferred operatorship to Quantum for the assets involved in our southern asset divestiture.
We have begun marketing our remaining East Texas, North Louisiana, and Haynesville assets at this time and should have that out in the next few weeks. Assuming we receive an acceptable offer for these assets, closing is not expected until sometime in the fourth quarter.
We’re also marketing our Cleveland Sand Play in Northwest Oklahoma, which we acquired as part of the Encore acquisition. We’re expecting bids on the Cleveland Sand Play imminently and assuming we receive an acceptable offer, we would expect to close this sale during the third quarter. Assuming we are successful in all these divestiture efforts, we will have essentially completed our rationalization efforts outlined as part of the Encore acquisition strategy.
With that, I’ll turn it over to Bob to talk about operations.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thank you, Tracy. I’ll give you a quick update on the major CO2 EOR fields and some of Bakken activity that we had during the second quarter.Tertiary production averaged 28,507 net BOEs per day for the quarter. That’s an increase of 1,484 net B
componenttext:
Yes. Thank you, Tracy. I’ll give you a quick update on the major CO2 EOR fields and some of Bakken activity that we had during the second quarter.
Tertiary production averaged 28,507 net BOEs per day for the quarter. That’s an increase of 1,484 net BOEs or about 5% compared to the first quarter of 2010, and then based on this increase in tertiary production rates, we are raising our average daily tertiary production guidance to 28,000 net BOEs average for the year.
We currently have 14 different fields under CO2 injection in six of our eight phases of expansion. With this limited time provided, I can’t go over all of them in detail, but I will touch on the highlights of the major fields. But overall, we continue to have a great success in our CO2 operations, with four of our fields exhibiting double-digit production growth during this quarter.
Phase 1 fields consisting of the six field areas in Southwest Mississippi increased by 382 BOEs per day or 3% increase over the first quarter, with an average daily rate of 12,347 net BOEs per day. The Little Creek area, the most matured area we operate, had a second quarter of double-digit growth.
The field averaged 1,971 net BOEs per day during the quarter, that’s a16.6% increase over the prior quarter. The increase was primarily due to response from a long-term non-responding wells and result of the WAG which is a Water Alternating Gas injection test that performed much better than expected.
During the quarter, this WAG program was expanded to two more Little Creek patterns in a high recovery area to test the potential of additional reserve recovery using this method.
At Brookhaven Field, we also established a four-patterned WAG program during May in our area that needs improvement. We are optimizing additional oil production; we will establish WAG in that area, we’d hope to see production by year end.
At McComb Smithdale, we decreased production by 129 net BOEs per day on a quarter-to-quarter basis, but at McComb, we have four wells that were drilled in the expansion area. They are being completed now. These wells should hopefully help us out, as we go through the year, to have positive impact on our production rates.
In the Mallalieu area, we increased production by 185 net BOEs or 5 percentage quarter-to-quarter, and at Lockhart Crossing, it continues to perform better than forecasted with the production growth of 16% plus quarter-to-quarter. Impact from five new wells should allow Lockhart Crossing to continue to increase further during the third and the fourth quarters of 2010.
Phase II experienced a 187 net barrel reduction in rate as compared to the first quarter; however, Heidelberg, about a 149 net BOEs per day increased 8.7% on a quarter-to-quarter basis. Our operational team continues to aggressively expand Heidelberg flood and expect to complete additional well sites and placed over 20 wells on line during the third quarter of this year.
Eucutta experienced 168 net BOE per day decrease. Eucutta is essentially fully developed, so we will continue to exhibit a decline. On a quarter-to-quarter basis, Soso Field was flat to last quarter and isn’t expected to change much for the rest of the year.
Martinville is where the smaller floods in Phase 2 has fluctuated up and down over the last couple of years, it decreased to 163 barrels per day in the second quarter.
For those of you that follow Denbury closely, you know that our Phase 3 EOR CO2 area is Tinsley Field. This reservoir continues to perform better than predicted. Tinsley Field increased 829 net BOEs per day, almost 19% quarter-to-quarter with a second quarter average production rate of 5,248 BOEs per day.
The addition of six wells in the Unit C’s [ph] fault block, there in the quarter along with other responding wells made the third consecutive quarter production increases with double digits.
Tinsley was aggressively expanded during 2009 and we continue to increase well count and our proved facility this year. We plan to invest in excess of $50 million into the Tinsley project during 2010.
Phase 4 is Cranfield, production decreased slightly, 125 net BOEs per day quarter-to-quarter. The decline is partly due to delay in our drilling program. The drilling rig we had under contract we used to develop other Denbury tertiary field during the first and second quarters, but the rig has now returned to Cranfield and it’s now in operations. We will drill and complete the 12 wells 2010 capital drilling program during the third and fourth quarters of this year.
At Delhi, which is our Phase 5, CO2 expansion continues in the (inaudible) Tuscaloosa formations. Purchased CO2 injection increased to an average 84 million cubic feet a day during the quarter. As the reservoir pressure increases, additional oil response is expected during the year.
Second quarter average production was 648 net BOEs per day, that’s up from 63 BOEs per day during the first quarter. The EOR production continues to run above forecast as a result of earlier than expected response and then currently 16 wells are flowing into the production system at various flow rates and oil rates, and we have completed our 20 well 2010 drilling program and we’ll continue to expand the facilities there at Delhi.
Phases 7 and 8 are the Hastings and Oyster Bayou Field respectively, those filed of course are located along the Texas Gulf Coast. Progress in both fields is moving forward and on schedule. Oyster Bayou began injection on June 29. The current injection rate is approximately 44 million cubic feet a day at the three wells. And the first EOR production there is not expected until the second half of 2011.
Development continues with three capital rigs at Oyster Bayou along with the construction of our production and compression facilities. Hastings, we are running five capital rigs there, with current existing wells for CO2 injection, sometime early 2011 or late this year.
Jackson Dome, we need to talk about, our average production was 768 million cubic feet a day during the second quarter, that’s slightly ahead of our forecasted CO2 volumes. The drydock well, which is the Denbury 2916 #1 will be tested in the next few weeks, and this well should be placed in production during late 2010 or early 2011.
Currently, we also have two drilling rigs operated in the Gluckstadt field, which will increase our CO2 production levels later in 2010 or possibly 2011. These wells could also improve or increase our proved reserve if the field is found to have multiple fault blocks or separate compartments. Additional CO2 production from these wells will ensure that we have the deliverability to continue our field expansions along the Gulf Coast and Mississippi.
The 24-inch Green Pipeline construction was completed at the Oyster Bayou field late last year, and the first 260 miles were successfully packed and commissioned and is now transporting about 44 million cubic feet a day into Oyster Bayou. Now we have three remaining segments of the pipeline and those should be completed late this year to the Hastings field.
We have 19 miles from Oyster Bayou to the east side of Galveston Bay, and that will be hydrostatic tested either late August or the first week of September. The 14 miles of Galveston Bay crossing is underway, we have several miles of pipeline already constructed and we’ve already completed the drill on the Houston ship channel.
And then we have the remaining 25 miles on the west side of Galveston Bay, that’s underway. We have about 30% of the pipeline welled in. Like I said, our goal is to have the Green Pipeline in service to Hastings by year end or early 2011.
Moving from the Gulf Coast to Rocky Mountains, our 20 inch Green core pipeline is a 230 mile pipeline running from Lost Cabin, Wyoming up to Bell Creek, Montana. Right of ways in survey are undergoing with 95% of the surveys complete and about 41 of the right of way has been acquired.
We have preliminary engineering, it’s completed, finalizing the design pipe specifications. We work on the environmental assessment and the project should have a target start date of August 2011.
Bell Creek flood in Montana will be the first Rocky Mountain Denbury EOR flood, and we are right now recompleting idle water injection wells to CO2 service. Thus far 17 wells have been prepared for CO2 injection. We expect to have an additional 12 injection wells completed by the year end. That project start date will be sometime late 2012 or early 2013.
Mark mentioned lease operating expenses from the combined company. They decreased on a unit basis from $20.12 of BOE during the first quarter to $16.69 BOEs in second quarter. As we go through the year, we expect them to average slightly above $18 per BOE and we hope to maintain that expense rate.
If you look back and review the legacy Denbury lease operating expenses, they decreased 2% or $0.51 net BOE quarter-to-quarter from $22.86 in net BOE to $22.35 in net BOE. Electrical and fuel cost decreased, mostly that was 3.9%. Work-over cost also decreased 21%, primarily due to the operational improvements and procedures that we’ve instituted related to remedial work on the CO2 injection wells.
Contract labor did increase 22% due to capital activity and the contracting plan op raise during our expansions and startups. We continue to review our LOE cost, like changes to our process and procedures to hopefully maintain those levels.
Moving to the Williston Basin, North Dakota, we currently have three rigs working the Bakken formation. We contracted a fourth rig to commence drilling operations during September of 2010. Our fifth drilling rig is also planned to start drilling operations in the first quarter of 2011.
We have completed five Bakken wells to date and another three are in the process of being completed. One thing that we commonly do with the method of evaluating reserves potential is to just look at the average production rates for the first 30, 60, 90 days of production. The majority of our wells show pretty good response.
Early on, we completed Porcupine wells in March. We had one well that is the Sanish well on 640 acre, 12 stage frac. The 60-day average there was about 385 BOEs per day and the Porcupine also a Bakken well 640 acre, 12 stage at an average rate of over 498 BOEs per day for 60-day average.
The Werre Trust, another well in the Sanish area, which was 1280 acre, 19 stage, had a 60-day average of over 900 barrels oil per day. And then the last two that we have 60-day averages on are the Swenson, Charlson, Bakken completion 640 acre, 12 stage.
That well had a 60-day average of 873 BOEs per day and our Gilbertson, Charlson, Bakken well again a 640 acre, 12 stage at 619 average BOEs per day. I think Mark is going to put this information out on our web page in the next 24 to 48 hours.
Partly the Haynesville, Denbury has drilled three operating wells during 2010. Although we have ceased drilling operations and released our drilling rig there we are continuing to participate in wells operated by Chesapeake, JW, Blackhawk, Chemtura, El Paso, (inaudible) and to-date Denbury has participated in gross 23 wells during the year and expected to participate in additional nine gross wells AP [ph] by these operators.
Haynesville production in the second quarter averaged 3931 net BOEs per day. Production expected to fluctuate in the Haynesville depending on the timing of these completions, but we have two remaining wells Denbury operated that will be fraced before the end of the third quarter and that should also add to our rate during the third quarter.
With that, I’ll return it to Phil.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, guys. That’s all good news. As Bob mentioned, we will have update our presentation on the Web site probably the next day or two that will have the updated guidance by area, the Bakken results you just referred to, the wells that are drilling, th
componenttext:
Thanks, guys. That’s all good news. As Bob mentioned, we will have update our presentation on the Web site probably the next day or two that will have the updated guidance by area, the Bakken results you just referred to, the wells that are drilling, the updated Bakken potential, et cetera. So in case you missed some of those numbers, you can refer to our Web site shortly.
So that’s all good news for Denbury, let’s turn now to ENP, I’ve already kind of mentioned that the ENP strategic process is ongoing and it’s taken a bit long than we expected because we’ve been focused on the transaction at Elk Basin, but Mark will give you a brief update on the ENP numbers.

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: As announced last week, ENP’s distribution for the second quarter of 2010 was proved at $0.50 per unit, same distribution rate as Q1. Cash available for distribution in Q2 was $25 million as compared to $27.9 million in Q1, lower due primarily to lower
componenttext:
As announced last week, ENP’s distribution for the second quarter of 2010 was proved at $0.50 per unit, same distribution rate as Q1. Cash available for distribution in Q2 was $25 million as compared to $27.9 million in Q1, lower due primarily to lower production, price realization, and incremental G&A expense of $1 million associated with the hiring of investment advisor by the Conflicts Committee of the Board of Directors.
Our coverage ratio for the first quarter was just under 1.1 times. Production for the second quarter totaled 8,841 BOEs per day as compared to 9,034 BOEs per day in the first quarter of 2010. Going forward, we expect our production to continue to be on a gradual decline for the remainder of 2010. We repaid $5 million in bank debt during the quarter, bringing our bank debt to $245 million at June 30.
With that, I’ll turn it back to Phil.

componenttext: We’re pretty much using a tight decline for the reserves based on the 30-day average. So we use a (inaudible) point of 1.6 and final decline rate of about 8%. componenttext: To hold all the operated units that we’re forecasting, it’s five. That’s what we’ve scheduled out and that’s through 2011. headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Following up on a few Bakken questions. Can you talk about the completion techniques you guys are using there? Are you doing plug-and-perf or sliding sleeve?
componenttext: Following up on a few Bakken questions. Can you talk about the completion techniques you guys are using there? Are you doing plug-and-perf or sliding sleeve?

headline: Denbury Resources Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: No. We’re trying to standardize that. We’re going to use ball/sleeve method. The plug-and-perf, we’ve had some complications with the wireline, so we’re finding ball/sleeve is probably the most cost effective and expeditious to your stimulation ti
componenttext: No. We’re trying to standardize that. We’re going to use ball/sleeve method. The plug-and-perf, we’ve had some complications with the wireline, so we’re finding ball/sleeve is probably the most cost effective and expeditious to your stimulation timing and removes need for that wireline. So we’re using that method.

componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, it’s down to 3P, number one, so, I mean, generally, the one offset is proved and the third offset is either possible to bring on how it’s spaced. I mean, that’s just based on what you’re recovering today as the individual wells and y
componenttext: Well, I mean, it’s down to 3P, number one, so, I mean, generally, the one offset is proved and the third offset is either possible to bring on how it’s spaced. I mean, that’s just based on what you’re recovering today as the individual wells and you look at the amount of oil in place across a section or a unit. It looks like it’s going to take at least three wells to get a reasonable recovery.
